div.p: Know your own Mind: A COMEDY, PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, IN COVENT-GARDEN.
Know your own Mind: A COMEDY, PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, IN COVENT-GARDEN.

q.l: Quod petiit, ſpernit; repetit quod nuper omiſit;

div.q: Ut callidum ejus ingenium, ita anxium judicium. TACIT.
div.p: LONDON: Printed for T. BECKET, Adelphi, in the Strand.

lg.l: THROUGH the wide tracts of life, in every trade,
What numbers toil with faculties decay'd?
Worn out, yet eager,— in the race they run,
And never learn—when proper to have done.
What need of proofs? Ev'n Authors do the ſame,
And rather than deſiſt decline in fame.
Like Gameſters thrive at firſt; then bolder grow,
And hazard all upon one deſp'rate throw.
This truth to feel, perhaps too much inclin'd,
Our Bard, long hackney'd, trembles there behind,
Leſt he ſhould prove—another VANISH'D MIND.
Long has this play lain hid, ſuppreſs'd by fears,
Beyond the critics rule, ABOVE NINE YEARS!
And now he comes, 'tis the plain ſimple truth,
This night to anſwer for his ſins of youth.
The piece, you'll ſay, ſhould now perfection bear;
But who can reach it after all his care?
He paints no monſters for ill judg'd applauſe:
Life he has view'd, and from that ſource he draws.
Here are no fools, the Drama's ſtanding jeſt!
And WELCHMEN now, NORTH-BRITONS too may reſt.
HIBERNIA'S SONS ſhall here excite no wonder,
Nor ſhall ST. PATRICK bluſh to hear them blunder.
By other arts he ſtrives your taſte to hit,
Some plot, ſome character; he hopes, ſome wit.
And if this piece ſhould pleaſe you like the paſt;
Ye Brother Bards! forgive him:—'tis his laſt.
Loſt are the friends who lent their aid before;
ROSCIUS retires, and BARRY is no more.
Harmonious BARRY! with what varied art
His grief, rage, tenderneſs aſſail'd the heart?
Of plaintive OTWAY now no more the boaſt!
And SHAKESPEARE grieves for his OTHELLO loſt.
Oft on this ſpot the tuneful ſwan expir'd,
Warbling his grief;—you liſten'd and admir
'Twas then but fancy'd woe; now ev'ry Muſe,
Her lyre unſtrung, with tears his urn bedews.
From this night's ſcenes e'n WOODWARD too is fled,
Stretch'd by pale ſickneſs on his languid bed,

Nor can THALIA raiſe her FAVOURITE'sMr. WOODWARD was to have played the part of DASHWOULD: in his laſt illneſs he lamented to the Author, that he could not cloſe his theatrical life with that character: he died a few weeks after the play appeared; for years the life of the comic ſcene, and in his end regretted as a worthy and an honeſt man. head.
For them our Author lov'd the tale to weave;
He feels their loſs; and now he takes his leave;
Sees new performers in ſucceſſion ſpring,
And hopes new poets will expand their wing.
Beneath your ſmile his leaf of laurel grew;
Gladly he'd keep it;—for 'twas giv'n by you.
But if too weak his art, if wild his aim,
On favours paſt he builds no idle claim:
To you once more he boldly dares to truſt;
HEAR, and pronounce;—he KNOWS you will be juſt.

div.head: ACT the FIRST.
div.stage: Scene, the Houſe of Sir JOHN MILLAMOUR.

sp.speaker: BYGROVE.
sp.p: WHY then I'd marry again, and diſinherit him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Brother Bygrove, you think too ſeverely in theſe matters.

sp.speaker: BYGROVE.
sp.p: Severely, Sir John? If I had a mind that my ſon ſhould marry, why ſhould he not do as I would have him?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Allowance muſt be made for inclination. The ſucceſs of our children depends upon the manner, in which we ſet them out in the world. They are like bowls which, if deliver'd out of hand with a due regard to their bias, our aim is anſwer'd, if otherwiſe, they are ſhort or wide of the mark in view, or perhaps ruſh wildly out of the green.

sp.speaker: BYGROVE.
sp.p: Well argued, truly! he that ſhould obey is to judge for himſelf, and you that are his governor, are to be directed by him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Why he is chiefly intereſted in the end, and the choice of the means may be fairly left to himſelf. I can't but be tender of George; a plant of my own rearing, and the tree will hereafter be known by its fruit.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: It is a tree that will bear nothing without grafting; and if I could not inoculate what will make it thrive and flouriſh, it ſhould not incumber a foot of my land.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Your ſyſtem and mine differ widely, Brother Bygrove. My ſon is of a large and liberal underſtanding, and I a father of mild authority.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Authority!—your ſon's word is a law to you. Now there is my young graceleſs; he is in the army, and why? Becauſe I choſe it. I had a mind he ſhould ſerve; and ſo he went to be ſhot at. No arguing with me. If I ſee any thing wrong, I accoſt him directly: Look ye, Sir, do you think to go on in this faſhion? Not during my life, I promiſe you: I will acknowledge you no longer than you prove worthy; and if you can't diſcern what is befitting you, I at leaſt will judge what is proper on my part.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Well, George and I have lived together as friends. From a boy, I endeavoured to ſubject him rather to his reaſon, than his fears. If any little irregularity happened, he was no ſooner ſenſible of it, than his cheek coloured, and the bluſh of youth not only looked decent, but expreſſed an ingenuous and well-diſpoſed mind.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: But the conſequence of all this? Has he a ſettled opinion? a fixed principle for a moment? He is grown up in caprice; his judgment has not vigour to be deciſive upon the mereſt trifle; he is deſtracted by little things, and of courſe is periſhing by little and little.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! no; all from a good cauſe; his knowledge of life occaſions quick reflection: quick reflection ſhews things in a variety of lights. I am not angry. He will ſettle in the world; you will ſee him married before long.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: In what a variety of lights his wife will appear to him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I beg your pardon for a moment. I ſee perſon there. Charles, Charles, this way.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Well, Charles, what is he about?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Very buſy, Sir, a thouſand things in hand.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And all at the ſame time, I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: We have a deal to employ us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Have you ſounded him in regard to what I mentioned laſt night?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: That's what I wanted to tell your Honour. Laſt night, Sir, as he was going to bed, I touch'd upon the ſubject; dropt a hint or two, that it is now time to think of raiſing heirs to himſelf; enlarged upon the comforts of matrimony, and I think with no ſmall degree of eloquence.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: The fellow is laughing at you.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Well, and how? What effect?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: A very viſible effect, Sir. This morning early, my maſter rings his bell. Charles, ſays he, I have been conſidering what you ſaid laſt night: I ſhall pay a viſit to the young ladies, and, I believe, I ſhall marry one of them.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: There, Mr. Bygrove; I am for ever obliged to you, Charles. Well, go on.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: I fly immediately to get him his things to dreſs, and return in an inſtant. Charles, ſays he, then toſſed himſelf back in his chair, beat the ground with his heel, and fell a reading. Won't your Honour get ready to viſit the young ladies?—The ladies? what ladies, you blockhead?—Lady Bell, and Lady Jane, your Honour, Mrs. Bromley's handſome nieces. Po! you're a numſkull, ſays he, with an oblique kind of a ſmile; ſtretched his arms, yawned, talked to himſelf, and bade me go about my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p:
I knew it would end ſo. There is not a crane-neck carriage in town can give a ſhort turn with
him. He will continue going on from one thing to another, and end in nothing at laſt.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This is provoking. Any body with him this morning?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: He has had a power of people with him, Sir—A commiſſion-broker, to ſell him a company in a marching regiment; the Mayor of a borough, about a ſeat in parliament. And there are ſeveral with him now, Sir. There is Sir Harry Lovewit, and—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Aye! Sir Harry! I am glad he is of age, and that I am no longer his guardian. He has not had a new idea in his head ſince he was five years old, and yet the blockhead affects to be lively. He runs after wits, who do nothing but laugh at him. He repeats ſcraps and ſentences; all memory and no underſtanding; a mere retailer of what falls from other people, and with that ſtock he ſets up for a wit.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: He is with my maſter, Sir; and there is Mr. Malvil, and Mr. Daſhwould, and—(bell rings) —He rings, Sir: you will pardon me; I muſt be gone, Sir.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And that fellow, Daſhwould; he is the ruin of your ſon, and of poor Sir Harry into the bargain. He is the Merry Andrew of the town: honour has no reſtraint upon him; truth he ſets at nought, and friendſhip he is ever ready to ſacrifice to a joke.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Po! mere innocent pleaſantry. Daſhwould has no harm in him.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No harm in him? I grant you the fellow has a quick ſenſe of the ridiculous, and draws a character with a lucky hit. But every thing is diſtorted by him. He has wit to ridicule you; invention to frame a ſtory of you; humour to help it about, and when he has ſet the town a laughing, he puts on a familiar air, and ſhakes you by the hand.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! I ſhall certainly expire one day, in a fit of laughing.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: What fool's errand brings him hither?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: That fellow, Daſhwould, will be the death of me. The very ſpirit of whim, wit, humour, and raillery poſſeſs him.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Ay! wit and humour for the meridian of your underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: By the ſhade of Rablais, he is the moſt entertaining creature! He has play'd off ſuch a fire-work of wit. I'll tell you what he ſaid this moment.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No, Sir, no; if you are a pedlar in ſmart ſayings and briſk repartees, we don't deſire you to unpack for us.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: A plague on him for an agreeable devil! And then the rogue has ſo much eaſe.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Yes, the eaſe of an executioner. He puts all to death without remorſe. He laughs at every thing, as if Heaven intended to make its own work ridiculous. He has no reliſh for beauty, natural or moral. He is in love with deformity, and never better pleaſed, than when he has moſt reaſon to find fault.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: There is a picture of as harſh features as any in Daſhwould's whole collection.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: But the picture is true. No exaggerationin it.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: He gave us a miniature of you, this morning, my dear guardian, and you ſhall have it. Daſhwould has made a diſcovery, Sir John. What reaſon do you think he gives for Mr. Bygrove's railing for ever at your ſon's inconſtancy of temper?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Ay, now! now!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: You poſitively ſhall hear it. Mr. Bygrove's deſires being all ruſted to a point, looking directly toward the land of matrimony—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Matrimony! now gild the pill with humour, and down it goes.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Daſhwould has found you out. Mr. Bygrove's deſires being all collected and fixed on matrimony, he rails at the variety of my friend Milamour's whimſies, like Sir George Bumper, with chalkſtones on his knuckles, as big as nutmegs, hobbling along and thanking Doctor Le Fevre that he has no ſmall humours flying about him.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: That's a diſcovery indeed.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Sir John, can you mind what ſuch a fellow as Daſhwould ſays? Every thing that paſſes through the medium of his fancy appears deformed, as the ſtraiteſt ſtick looks crooked in troubled water.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Well daſhed out, upon my ſoul, with tolerable ſpleen, and ſome vivacity.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po!—if you had taken my advice, Sir Harry and renounced his acquaintance long ago, you had been now a young man coming into life, with ſome promiſe of a character. Continue in diſſipation, Sir. For my part it is a rule with me, neither to give nor take a joke.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Ho! ho! ho! a pleaſant rule, poſitively —ho! ho! ho! Daſhwould ſhall have it this moment; do you take the conſequence; and in the mean time, I'll leave you to the practice of your ſocial humour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: It is ſuch coxcombs as that butterfly, that encourage him to fix his paſquinades upon every man's character. Matrimony!—a licentious— No, Sir John, I ſtill cheriſh the memory of your ſiſter; ſhe was the beſt of wives; 'ſdeath, interrupted again by that—No, it's my friend Malvil; he is a man of true value.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Daſhwould ſays, he is a compound of falſe charity, and real malice.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And it is enough for you that Daſhwould ſays it. Malvil is a man of honour, Sir; and an enemy to all ſcandal, though wit prove a palateable ingredient in the poiſon.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Intolerable! there is no being ſafe where he is. A licentious railer! All truth, all morality ſacrificed to a jeſt: nothing ſacred from his buffoonery.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: I told you, Sir John, how it is.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Oh! ſuch indiſcriminate ſatire!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Yes, the fellow runs a muck, and nothing eſcapes him.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: There is no enduring it. Ridicule is a very unfair weapon, Mr. Bygrove: it is by no means the teſt of truth, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Nay, but you are too grave about this matter.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Too grave! Shall he wantonly ſtab the reputation of his neighbour, and then tell you it was in jeſt? For my part, I had rather throw a veil over the infirmities of my friend, than ſeek a malicious pleaſure in the detection. That's my way of thinking.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I fancy you are right. This ſon of mine does ſo perplex me.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Bygrove, give me leave. I am ſorry to hear certain whiſpers about a friend of ours.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: About whom? the widow, Mrs. Bromley?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Oh! no, no; I have a great reſpect for her: though I—Pray don't you think ſhe throws out the lure for a young huſband?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: For a huſband, yes, but not too young a one; you can ſerve my intereſt in that quarter.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I know it: rely upon my friendſhip. But have you heard nothing of an eminent Turkey merchant?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Mr. Freeport?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I ſay nothing: I don't like the affair: have you really heard nothing?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: So much the better: though it is fit you ſhould be put upon your guard. Any money of yours in his hands?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po! as ſafe as the bank.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I may be miſtaken. I hope I am: I was in company the other night; ſeveral members of parliament preſent; they did not ſpeak plainly; hints and inuendos only; you won't let it go any further. His ſeat in the houſe they all agreed, is perfectly convenient at this juncture. I hope the cloud will blow over.—I ſhall remember you with the widow.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: One good turn deſerves another: I ſhan't be unmindful of your intereſt.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: There, now you hurt me: you know my delicacy: muſt friendſhip never act a diſintereſted part? I eſteem you, Mr. Bygrove, and that's ſufficient. Sir John, give me leave to ſay, the man who buſies himſelf about other people's affairs, is a pragmatical character, and very dangerous in ſociety.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: So I have been telling Sir John. But to laugh at every thing is the faſhion of the age. A pleaſant good-for-nothing fellow is by moſt people preferred to modeſt merit. A man like Daſhwould, who runs on—So! here come Scandal in folio.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Sir John, I rejoice to ſee you. Mr. Bygrove, I kiſs your hand. Malvil, have you been uneaſy for any friend ſince?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Po! abſurd!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I have been laughing with your ſon, Sir John. Pray have I told you about Sir Richard Doriland?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You may ſpare him, Sir, he is a very worthy man.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He is ſo: great good-nature about him: I love Sir Richard. You know he was divorced from his wife; a good fine woman, but an invincible ideot.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Look ye there now, Mr. Bygrove!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: My Lady Doriland, Sir, was always counted a very ſenſible woman.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: She was ſo; with too much ſpirit to be ever at eaſe, and a rage for pleaſure, that broke the bubble as ſhe graſped it. She fainted away upon hearing that Mrs. All-night had two card tables more than herſelf.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Inveterate malice!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: They waged war a whole winter, for the honour of having the greateſt number of fools thinking of nothing but the odd trick. Firſt, Mrs. All-night kept Sundays; her Ladyſhip did the ſame: Mrs. All-night had forty tables; her Ladyſhip roſe to fifty. Then one added, then t'other; 'till every room in the houſe was cramm'd like the black hole at Calcutta; and at laſt, upon caſting up the account, Sir Richard ſold off fifteen hundred acres, to clear incumbrances.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ridiculous! and ſo they parted upon this?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Don't you know the hiſtory of that buſineſs?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Now mark him; now.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Tender of reputation, Malvil!—The ſtory is well known. She was detected with—the little foreign Count—I call him the Salamander—I ſaw him ſive times in one winter upon the back of the fire at Bath, for cheating at cards.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Go on, Sir, abuſe every body. My Lady was perfectly innocent. I know the whole affair: a mere contrivance to lay the foundation of a divorce.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: So they gave our. Sir Richard did not care a nine-pin for her while ſhe was his. You know his way: he deſpiſes what is in his poſſeſſion, and languiſhes for what is not. Her Ladyſhip was no ſooner married to—what's his name?—His father was a footman, and Madam Fortune, who every now and then loves a joke, ſent him to the Eaſt Indies, and in a few years brought him back at the head of half a million, for the jeſt's ſake.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mr. Daſhwould, upon my word, Sir, — Families to be run down in this manner!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Muſhroon was his name: my Lady Doriland was no ſooner married to him, but up to his eyes Sir Richard was in love with her. He dreſſed at her; ſighed at her; danced at her; ſhe is now libelled in the Commons, and Sir Richard has a crim. con. againſt him in the King's Bench.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Pſhaw! I ſhall ſtay no longer to hear this ſtrain of defamation.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Malvil, muſt you leave us? A pleaſant character this ſame Mr. Malvil.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: He has a proper regard for his friends, Sir.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes, but he is often preſent where their characters are canvaſſed, and is anxious about whiſpers which nobody has heard. He knows the uſe of hypocriſy better than a Court Chaplain.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: There, call honeſty by a burleſque name, and ſo pervert every thing.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Things are more perverted, Mr. Bygrove, when ſuch men as Malvil make their vices do their work, under a maſk of goodneſs; and with that ſtroke we'll diſmiſs his character.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Ay, very right; my brother Bygrove has a regard for him, and to change the ſubject. My ſon, Mr. Daſhwould, what does he intend?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Up to the eyes in love with Lady Bell, and determined to marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I told you ſo, Mr. Bygrove; I told you, you would ſoon ſee him ſettled in the world. Mr. Daſhwould, I thank you; I'll ſtep and conſirm George in his reſolution.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A good-natur'd man, Sir John, and does not want credulity,

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Ay! there, the moment his back is turned.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Gulliver's Travels is a true hiſtory to him. His ſon has ſtrange flights. Firſt he was to be a lawyer; bought chambers in the Temple, eat his commons, and was called to the bar. Then the law is a damn'd dry, municipal ſtudy; the army is fitter for a gentleman; and as he was going to the Waroffice to take out his commiſſion, he ſaw my Lord Chancellor's coach go by; in an inſtant, back to the Temple, and no ſooner there, Po! pox! hang the law; better marry, and live like a gentleman. Now marriage is a galling yoke, and he does not know what he'll do. He calls his man Charles; ſends him away; walks about the room; ſits down; aſks a queſtion; thinks of ſomething elſe; talks to himſelf, ſings, whiſtles, lively, penſive, pleaſant, and melancholy in an inſtant. He approves, ſinds fault; he will, he will not; and in ſhort, the man does not know his own mind for half a ſecond.—Here comes Sir John.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You find him diſpoſed to marry, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I hope ſo; he wavers a little; but ſtill I—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po! I have no patience; my advice has been all loſt upon you. I wiſh it may end well. A good morning, Sir John.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Mr. Bygrove, your's: Sir John will defend you in your abſence.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: If you will forget your friends in their abſence, it is the greateſt favour you can beſtow upon them.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Did I ever tell you what happened to him laſt ſummer, at Tunbridge?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Excuſe me for the preſent: This light young man! I muſt ſtep, and talk with my lawyer.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I'll walk part of the way with you. A ſtrange medley this ſame Mr. Bygrove: with ſomething like wit, he is always abuſing wit.—You muſt know, laſt ſummer, at Tunbridge—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Another time, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The ſtory is worth your hearing: a party of us dined at the Suſſex—

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Mr. Daſhwould! Mr. Daſhwould!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What's the matter, Charles?

sp.speaker: CHA.
sp.p: My maſter deſires you won't go.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Hey! what going to leave us?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Only a ſtep with Sir John. Strange vagaries in your maſter's head, Charles!—Sir Harry! going to wait upon Miſs Neville, I ſuppoſe. She has beauty, and you have a heart.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Pſhaw! there you wrong me now! Why will you?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Very well; be it ſo; I can't ſee to be ſure; but take my word for it, you will marry that girl. Come, I follow you.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I muſt not part with you: I had rather loſe the whole College of Phyſicians.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: March on, Sir Harry.— (turns to Charles) Did you ever ſee ſuch a Baronet? This fellow, Charles, is as ridiculous himſelf as any of them.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Now have I but one man in the houſe, and he will be fifty different men in a moment. Hurry! hurry! nothing but hurry! Get me this; get me that; get me t'other; bring me the blue and ſilver; ſcoundrel! what do you fetch me this for? let me have the brown and gold. A poor ſervant does not know which way to turn himſelf in this houſe.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Well, Richard, what are you about?

sp.speaker: RICH.
sp.p: Why a man in a whirlwind may as well tell what he is about. Going to order the coachman to put up. He intends to change his dreſs, and walk to the Temple.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: What does he mean by talking of the Temple again? I hope we are not going to take to our ſtudies once more. I hate the law: there is not a footman in the Temple has a grain of taſte. All mere lawyers! They have not an idea out of the profeſſion.

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Richard! Richard! where is he gone?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: What's in the wind now?

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: The wind's in another quarter. He has been writing verſes as he calls them, ever ſince the company left him. He has torn a quire of paper, I believe, and now he wants the carriage directly.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Run and order it. I had rather be a country curate, than go on in this manner. (bell rings) What is he at now?

sp.speaker: MILLAMOUR.
sp.p: Charles:—who anſwers there?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Ay; now for the old work.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Is the chariot ready?

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: At the door, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Do you ſtep to Mrs. Bromley's, and—perhaps it would be better to—No, do you ſtep, Charles, and—you need not mind it—another time will do as well.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: There again now: this is the way from morning to night.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: The ſooner the better: I promiſed Sir John, and I will pay this viſit. Lady Bell reigns ſovereign of my heart. That vivacity of mind! "Quick as her eyes, and as unfix'd as thoſe."

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: She is by far preferable to her ſiſter, your Honour.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Po! you are illiterate in theſe matters. The ſober graces of Lady Jane!—Lady Bell advances like a conqueror, and demands your heart: Lady Jane ſeems unconſcious of her charms, and yet enſlaves you deeper.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Which of them does your Honour think—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Which of'em, Charles? (reads a paper) "I look'd, and I ſigh'd, and I wiſh'd I could ſpeak."

sp.speaker: ROB.
sp.p: Captain Bygrove, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: That's unlucky. I am not at home; tell him I went out an hour ago.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: My dear Bygrove, I longed to ſee you. But why that penſive air? Still in love, I ſuppoſe,

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: My dear Millamour, you have gueſſed it. I am in love, and I glory in my chains.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Shall I tell you a ſecret? I ſuſpect myſelf, plaguily. Every thing is not as quiet here as it uſed to be.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Indulge the happy paſſion. Let wits and libertines ſay what they will; 'there is no true happineſs, but in the married ſtate.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Why I have thought much upon the ſubject of late, and with a certain refinement, I don't know but a man may faſhion a complying girl to his taſte of happineſs. Virtuous himſelf, he confirms her in her virtue; conſtant, he ſecures her fidelity: and by continuing the lover, inſtead of commencing the tyrant huſband, he wins from her the ſweeteſt exertion of tenderneſs and love. I ſhall moſt poſitively marry. Who is your idol? My dear boy, impart.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: There I beg to be excuſed. You know my father. I muſt not preſume to think for myſelf. I muſt contrive ſome ſtratagem to make him propoſe the match. Were it to move firſt from me, I ſhould be obliged to decamp from before the town at once.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I wiſh you ſucceſs. My reſolution is taken, and with the moſt amiable of her ſex. She romps about the room like one of the Graces; and deals about her wit with ſuch a happy negligence—

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: An agreeable portrait, but mine is the very reverſe. That equal ſerenity in all her ways! Wit ſhe has, but without oſtentation; and elegance itſelf ſeems the pure effect of nature.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I don't know whether that is not the true character for a wife. And pray, what progreſs have you made in her affections?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Enough to convince me that I am not quite unacceptable My dear Millamour, I had rather fold that girl in my arms, than kiſs his Majeſty's hand for the firſt regiment of guards.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I am a loſt man, I ſhall moſt poſitively marry. We will wonder at each others felicity; and be the envy of all our acquaintance.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I am as good as my word, you ſee. Moſt noble Captain, your father was here this morning. A good agreeable old gentleman, and about as pleaſant as a night mare. Millamour, whom do you think I met ſince I ſaw you?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Our friend Beverly, juſt imported from Paris, perfectly frenchified, and abuſing every thing in this country— Oh! there is no breathing their Engliſh atmoſphere.—Roaſt beef and liberty will be the death of me.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! poor Beverley! I ſaw him, laſt ſummer, at Paris, dreſſed in the ſtile of an Engliſh fox-hunter: he ſwore there was not a morſel to eat in their country; kept an opera-ſinger upon beef-ſteaks and oyſter-ſauce; drove to his villa every Saturday in a phaeton, and returned on the Monday, like a young Buck, juſt come upon town.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He has done his country great honour abroad.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: He will ſettle at home now: he is going to he married.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes, I hear he is in love, and much good may it do him. I wiſh I may die, if I know ſo ridiculous a thing as love.— My life!—My ſoul!—Hybla dwells upon her lips; extaſy and bliſs! blank verſe and paſtoral nonſenſe! In a I'ttle time, the man wonders what bewitched him: an arm chair after dinner, and a box and dice till five in the morning, make all the comforts of his life.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Very true! Love is a ridiculous paſſion indeed.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Do you take up arms againſt me? But a moment ſince, juſt as you came in, he was acknowledging to me—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p:
No, not I, truly; I acknowledge nothing.
Marriage is not to my taſte, I promiſe you. The handſome wife!—ſhe is all affectation; routs, drums, hurricanes, and intrigue!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And the ugly! ſhe makes it up with good ſenſe; pronounces upon wit! and talks you dead with maxims, characters, and reflections.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And the woman of high birth, ſhe produces her pedigree, as her patent for vice and folly. "Seven's the main," and away goes your whole fortune.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Mere common place.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And the tender maukin! ſhe doats upon you. Don't drink any more, my dear: you'll take cold near that window, my love; pray don't talk ſo much; you'll flurry your ſpirits—And then kiſſes you before company.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And the ſick madam! ſhe has the vapours, and finds that ſhe has nerves.—"I wiſh I had none.'— But it is too true that I have nerves, as ſlight as ſo many hairs.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Ha! ha! the whole ſex is divided into ſo many claſſes of folly.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Right! ſo it is. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: You play finely into one another's hands.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Now mark the champion of the ſex!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes; he'll throw down the gauntlet for 'em.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Nay, decide it your own way. Since you won't hear, gentlemen, there is a clear ſtage for you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Fare ye well, moſt noble Captain. A facetious companion! did you ever hear him ſay any thing?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: He is in for it; and my father would fain reduce me to the ſame condition with one of Mrs. Bromley's nieces. A good fine woman, Mrs. Bromley!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
Has been! Were ſhe now to rub her cheek
with a white handkerchief, her roſes and lilies would go to the clear ſtarcher.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! and yet ſhe ſets up for the rival, of her nieces.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The young ladies are pretty well in their way too. Lady Bell has a briſk volubility of nothing, that ſhe plays the pretty ideot with: and Lady Jane, a ſly piece of formality, ready to go poſt for Scotland, with the firſt red-coat that aſks her the queſtion. We all dine at the Widow's to day, are you to be with us?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, to meet you: the party will be diverting.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Obſerve old Bygrove. He pronounces with rigour upon the conduct of others, and hopes his own follies lie concealed. His whole ſtruggle is to eſcape detection, He hoodwinks himſelf, and thinks he blinds you. Poſitive and dogmatical in his opinions, yet a dupe to the deſigns of others; and flattering himſelf that a peeviſh and cenſorious ſpirit hides every defect, he gives you the full ridicule of his character.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I have marked him before now.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Mark him with the widow: you will ſee him ſighing for his deceaſed wife and Mrs. Bromley's charms at the ſame time. One eye ſhall weep for the dead, and the other ogle the living.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—And then Malvil laying ſiege to Miſs Neville!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Miſs Neville is the beſt of them. Mrs. Bromley has taken her into her houſe, as a poor relation, whom ſhe pities; and her pity is no more than the cruel art of tormenting an unhappy dependant upon her generoſity.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: But ſhe has generoſity. She has promiſed Miſs Neville a fortune of five thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And ſo the hook is baited for Malvil. The widow flings out that ſnare, to counteract Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Sir Harry!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes; he is in love with Miſs Neville; and the beſt of the ſtory is, he is afraid I ſhall think him ridiculous. If I ſay the word, and promiſe not to laugh at him, he breaks his mind at once. Miſs Neville ſees clearly that he admires her, and of courſe will never liſten to Malvil. The ſelf-intereſted deſigns of that fellow ſhall be diſappointed.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Admirable! thou art a whimſical fellow. Come, I attend you. A pleaſant group they are all together. It is as you ſay,
sp.l: Ours paſſions ſicken, and our pleaſures cloy;
A fool to laugh at, is the height of joy.

div.head: ACT the SECOND.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. BROMLEY, and Miſs NEVILLE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROMLEY.
sp.p: WHY, to be ſure, Neville, there is ſomething in what you ſay; one is ſo odd, and ſo I don't know how in a morning.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Certainly, madam; and then people of your turn, whoſe wit overflows in converſation, are liable to a waſte of ſpirits, and the alteration appears ſooner in them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: So it does: you obſerve very prettily upon things. Heigho! I am as faded as an old luteſtring to-day.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: No indeed, madam, you look very tolerably, conſideting.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Conſidering! ſhe grows pert, I think.—I am glad you think me not altogether intolerable.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Tolerably! ſhe is Lady Bell's prime agent (aſide). Has Sir Harry given you hopes lately?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Sir Harry! I really don't underſtand why he is mentioned.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Do you think it will be a match? And have you made up your quarrel with Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: The ſweetneſs of her diſpoſition reconciles every thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: And is Millamour reconciled to Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: There was only a ſlight miſtake, which I explained.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Oh! you explained? that was prudently done; I am glad to hear this: and do you think he loves her? Tell me; tell me all. Why? why do you think he loves her?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: He cannot be inſenſible of her merit; and the other day he aſked me if you were likely to approve of his propoſing for Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: And you told him.—Well!— what did you tell him?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: That you, no doubt, would be ready to promote the happineſs of ſo amiable a young lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You told him ſo? (riſes and walks about) And ſo you are turned match-maker: you buſy yourſelf in my family?—Hey!—Mrs. Start-up! you are dizened out, I think: my wardrobe has ſupplied you.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Your pardon, ma'am: I had theſe things in the country, when you firſt ſhewed ſo much goodneſs to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: What airs! you know I hate to ſee creatures give themſelves airs. Was not I obliged to provide you with every thing?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You have been very kind; I always acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Acknowledge it! Does not every body know it.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am. I dare ſay every body does know it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: That's maliciouſly ſaid: I can ſpy a ſneer upon that falſe face. You ſuppoſe I have made my brags. That's what lurks in your ambiguous meaning. I deſerve it: deliver me from poor relations.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Now the ſtorm begins! I am ſure I have ſaid nothing to offend you. I am helpleſs, it is true, but your relation, and by that tie a gentlewoman ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I made you a gentlewoman. Did not I take you up in the country, where you lived in the parſonage-houſe, you, and your ſiſter, with no other company to converſe with, than the melancholy tomb-ſtones, where you read the high and mighty characters of John Hodge, and Deborah his wife? While your father's miſerable horſe, worn to a ſhadow with carrying double to the next markettown, limped about, with a dull alms begging eye in queſt of the wretched ſuſtenance, that grew thriftily between the graves? Did not I take you out of your miſery?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You did, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Did not I bring you home to the great houſe?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You did, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: And I am finely thanked for it. Warm the ſnake, and it will turn upon you.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I cannot bear to be inſulted thus!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: So! your ſpirit is humbled, is it?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p:
Give me leave to tell you, madam, that when people of ſuperior fortune, whom Providence
has enabled to beſtow obligations, claim a right, from the favours they confer, to tyrannize over the hopes and fears of a mind in diſtreſs; they exerciſe a cruelty more barbarous than any in the whole hiſtory of human malice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Is this your gratitude?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I could be thankful for happineſs, if you permitted me to enjoy it: but when I find myſelf, under colour of protection, made the ſport of every ſudden whim; I have a ſpirit, madam, that can diſtinguiſh between real benevolence, and the pride of riches.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: O brave! that is your ſpirit!

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: A ſpirit, give me leave to ſay, that would rather, in any obſcure corner, ſubmit to drudgery, for a ſlender pittance, than continue to be an unhappy ſubject, for cruelty to try its experiments upon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I faney I have been too violent. After all this ſower, I muſt ſweeten her a little. Come, dry up your tears: you know I am goodnatured in the main. I am only jealous, that you dont't ſeem to love me.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Were that left to my own heart, every principle there would attach me to you. But to be dunned for gratitude!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You are right; the obſervation is very juſt: I am in the wrong.—Come, let us be friends, I have a great regard for you, Neville. (walks aſide) The creature ſhould viſit with me, only ſhe looks ſo well—How! did not I hear Mr. Malvil's voice? yes, it is he; I am viſible; I am at home; ſhew him in. Walk in, Mr. Malvil.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: To a perſon of ſentiment, like you, madam, a viſit is paid with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You are very good to me. Neville, do you ſtep and bring me the letter that lies upon my table (Exit Miſs Neville) I am obliged to go out this morning. (ſmiles at Malvil) She looks mighty well: I have been ſpeaking for you: our ſcheme will take. Sir Harry will not be able to rival you: ſhe will be your reward for all your ſervices to me.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Your generoſity is above all praiſe, and ſo I was ſaying this moment to Mr. Bygrove: he is coming to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: That's unlucky: I wanted to have ſome talk with you: well, have you ſeen Millamour▪

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Yes, and I find him apt: I have hopes of ſucceding.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Huſh!—not ſo loud!—you think me mad, I believe. May I hazard myſelf with that wild man?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Your virtue will reclaim him. I have a friendſhip for Millamour, and that is my reaſon for counteracting the deſigns of my friend Bygrove.—Mr. Bygrove has deſired me to ſpeak favourably of him to your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Oh! but he kept his laſt wife mew'd up in the country; I ſhould certainly expire in the country.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Why, I can't ſay much for a country life: you are perfectly right. Rooks and crows about your houſe; fox-hounds in full cry all the morning; the country 'ſquires as noiſy at dinner as their own hounds; diſputes about the game; commiſſioners of turnpikes, juſtices of the peace, and pedigrees of horſes; Oroonoko, brother to White Surry, got by Briſk Lightning, his dam by Bold Thunder. —That's the whole of their converſation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Deliver me! it would be the death of me. But don't tell Mr. Bygrove: amuſe him with hopes.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: He is a very worthy man. I am ſorry to ſee ſome oddities in him; but that is very common in life. Vices always border upon virtues. Daſh-would ſays, —but there is no believing his ſlander;— he ſays Mr. Bygrove's ſorrow for his deceaſed wife, is all mere artiſice, to weep himfelf into the good graces of another. But I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I hear him coming. Do you go and take care of your intereſt with Neville.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I obey your commands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I ſhall make her fortune five thoufand. Be ſure you ſpeak to Millamour. Go, go; ſucceſs attend you.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: This attention to one in my forlorn ſtate is ſo obliging—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: It is a favour on your part to receive aloſt, dejected, ſpiritleſs—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I admire your ſenſibility, Mr. Bygrove. That tender look, which you are for ever caſting back to a beloved, but irrecoverable object, ſhews ſo amiable a ſorrow! oh! there is ſomething exquiſite in virtuous affection.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Is this the letter you want, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I thank you, Neville. Yes, there is a luxury in hankering after a valuable perſon, who has been ſnatched away. I have found a pleaſing indulgence in contemplations of that ſort; have not I, Neville?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Ma'am! are you deaf? Are you ſtupid? I was telling Mr. Bygrove, what a taking I was in, when poor dear Mr. Bromley died.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I was not with you then, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Was not with me! what memories ſome folks have!—Go, and try if you can recover your memory: leave the room.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Ungenerous, narrow minded woman!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Oh! you little know what a profuſion of goodneſs I have laviſhed on that creature. She returns it all with ſullenneſs, with ill humour; with averſion. She perfectly remembers the affliction I was in, when I loſt the beſt of men.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: I have had my trials too. Heigho!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I beg your pardon: I am recalling your afflictions: you ſhould not give way; you ſhould ſtruggle a little. Heaven knows how I have ſtruggled. I have appeared, indeed, with an air, but it was all ſtruggling. (looks and ſmiles) I could divert you this morning. Do you know that your ſon is in love with lady Jane?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: In love! has he ſaid any thing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I don't know as to that; but I can ſee what is working in his heart. He is above ſtairs now: I don't half like his choice: Lady Bell is the proper match for him, and her fortune is the beſt. An eſtate, you know, muſt come to her, by the family ſettlement. You ſhould direct his choice.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: This comes of his preſuming to think for himſelf. Has he declared himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I fancy not; but he hinted ſomething to me, about a match in my family.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Why, a match in your family has diverted me of late—Heigho!—It is the only thing that has entertained me for a long time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I have had my fancies too. I ſhould like to talk further, but I am engaged abroad this morning. Can I ſet you down? Will you truſt yourſelt with me?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You encourage a ſmile, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: We ſhall be the town talk: but let them talk: what need we mind? I will juſt ſtep and ſay a word to Neville—You ſhould not be too ſolitary.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: So my friends tell me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I ſhall be with you in a moment. (returns) Do you know that we are very like each other in our tempers? After all, that is the true foundation of laſting friendſhips. Poor, dear Mr. Bromley! (going, returns) It was ſimilitude of temper brought us together; and if ever I could be prevailed upon again, ſimilitude of temper muſt do it. Well, you have diverted me this morning. Here comes your ſon, talk to him now.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what brings you to this houſe?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: A morning viſit, Sir; merely to kill half an hour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: There is nothing I hate ſo much as hypocriſy. I know your errand; you muſt pretend to be in love.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: I, Sir!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: What have you been ſaying to Lady Jane? I thought I had cautioned you againſt preſuming to think for yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: You have been very kind in that way.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: See what comes of your friend Millamour's being left to his own diſcretion. The aſs in the fable, divided in his choice, and ſtill doubting on, till it is too late to reſolve, gives but a faint image of him

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: And if I, Sir, to avoid his irreſolution—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p:
You are in the oppoſite extreme: he thinks too much and never decides. You never think at
all, and ſo reſolve without judgment. Take the advice of your friends before you come here to play the antic tricks of love; to kneel, cringe, fawn, flatter, and make yourſelf ridiculous. Do you know enough of the world to judge for yourſelf? Can you tell what they are all doing in the gay ſphere of life? The young are all bred up under the veterans of vice and folly. The ſee their mothers with autumnal faces, playing the agreeable, and forgeting that they are no longer young. The men are advanced beyond all former bounds, and the women preſs cloſe aſter them. A club for the ladies! intrepidity is now the female charm: to compleat their career, there is nothing left but to build a turf Coterie, at Newmarket, and ride their own matches, over the four mile courſe.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: An admirable picture, Sir; Daſh-would could not colour it higher.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Daſhwould! an indiſcriminate railer! I ſpeak for your good, and remember, I tell you, you know nothing of the world. After all, Sir; Lady Bell is the perſon I wiſh to ſee you married to:—go, and pay your addreſſes to her. I will ſettle that matter for you: you may then marry the perſon, to whom you have not degraded yourſelf, by pining, ſighing, love vetſes, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: This is all unaccountable to me, Sir. If you will but hear me—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No, Sir, no; I won't allow you to fetch a ſingle ſigh, till I ſay the word; when I give leave, you may then go and ſigh till your heart is ready to break. I'll hear no more: no parlying with me. Leave the houſe, this moment.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: I obey.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I interrupt you.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No, no; I am glad to ſee you. Well, have you had any opportunity with the widow?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I have; ſhe ſurprizes me a little: ſhe has dropt the maſk. I did not think ſhe had been ſo eager to marry. We had ſome talk about you. You know my heart: I am always true to my friends: I ſee but one difficulty: ſhe will never agree to live in the country.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: The lover need not diſpute that point, whatever the huſband may do hereafter.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Very true; and beſides, though I am not inclined, with the malicious part of the world, to ſuſpect her virtue, yet this town has temptations. It grieves me to ſee the ways of this great city; fine women without principle; friends without ſincerity: marriages to day, divorces to-morrow; whole eſtates ſet upon the caſt of a die; maſquerades without wit or humour; new comedies that make you cry, and tragedies that put you to ſleep: It grieves me to ſee all this. You are in the right to prefer good ſenſe and tranquility in the country.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. BROMLEY, and Miſs NEVILLE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, gentlemen. Neville, mind what I ſay to you: don't let thoſe giddy girls go out in my abſence; to walk in the Green Park, or run to hideous painters, under pretence of ſeeing odious pictures, that they may have an interview with more odious originals. Keep them at home; I will reward your pains. Allons, Mr. Bygrove. (Exit BYGROVE.) Come, Mr. Malvil.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Had not I better ſtay, and—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: No, no; come now, you may return to her.

sp.speaker: MAL. (to Miſs NEVILLE.)
sp.p: You ſee that I am torn from you; but I ſhall return as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p:
Tyrannical woman! ſome virtues ſhe has; but they are overſhadowed by their oppoſite qualities. Her love of praiſe, is a groſs appetite
of flattery. She oppreſſes with kindneſs, and her very civilities are ſure to be diſobliging. Oh! ſtate of dependance! for mere ſupport, to be ſubject every hour to caprice and arrogance!—Is it pride that makes me feel with this ſenſibillity?—No, my heart can anſwer it is not. I can bow to the hand that relives me; but I cannot ſtoop to the ſervile office of pampering vanity and oſtentation, with low and fulſome flattery. What does Lady Bell mean by talking to me of Sir Harry? She does it—I know her goodneſs—ſhe does it to ſoften affliction, and, if poſſible, divert a mind depreſſed with ſorrow. Sir Harry never threw away a thought on me. He behaves, indeed, with marked civility; but I don't know what to think of him. I muſt not aſpire too high: no, I have no pretenſions.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Miſs Neville, I am very angry with you. What is the matter? Has any thing made you uneaſy?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: No; I am not remarkable for high ſpirits, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Why would not you give us your company? How can you be ſo croſs? That ſiſter of mine is the verieſt madcap!

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Lady Bell is rather lively to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: But when ſhe once begins, ſhe hazards every thing, and talks ſometimes like a very libertine.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: The overflowing of gaiety, and good humour.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p:
I wiſh ſhe would reſtrain herſelf a little. Madam La Rouge is with her: ſhe has the ſweeteſt Point eyes ever beheld. I was endeavouring to cheapen it, but Lady Bell was ſo troubleſome;
ſhe called me a thouſand prudes, and will have it that nothing runs in my head but a lover.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I don't know but ſhe may be right. We are apt to deceive ourſelves. We talk of vapours, and fidgets, and retirement, but it is often artful, ſly, inſinuating man, that lurks at the bottom.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Well, I vow you'll make me hate you.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Has Captain Bygrove made no diſturbance in your heart?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: How can you? You are as great a plague as my ſiſter. As I live and breathe, the giddy romp is coming. You muſt take my part.

div.stage:
Lady BELL. (repeating)
Yes, I'm in love, I own it now,
And Caelia has undone me;
And yet, I ſwear, I can't tell how,
The pleaſing plague ſtole on me.
div.p: What would I give to have ſome miſerable ſwain talk in that ſtyle of me? "Belinda has undone me;" charming!

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: A lively imagination is a bleſſing, and you are happy, Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I am ſo: but then I am not talked of: I am loſing all my time.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Why, you bold creature! I hate to hear you talk with ſo much intrepidity.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Prudery! my dear ſiſter, downright pruderyl I am not for making myſteries of what all the world knows.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And how do I make myſteries pray?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Why, you confident thing! I'll prove it againſt you.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: But what? what? what will you prove?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: That you are ready to jump out of your little wits for a huſband, my demure, ſober ſiſter. Miſs Neville, a poet is not more eager for the ſucceſs of a new comedy, nor one of his brother poets more deſirous to ſee it fail, than that girl is to throw herſelf into the arms of a man.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: All ſcandal, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Miſs Neville ſhall be judge.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Your ſtory is mere invention.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a wrangler?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You'll not make good your words.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, Miſs, will you?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Very well, go on.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Will you have done? Now mind, Miſs Neville. She does not want to be married, ſhe ſays. The other night, my young Madam, whoſe thoughts are always compoſed and even, went to ſleep as ſoon as we got to bed, and then her buſy imagination went to work with all the vivacity of an intriguing chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And how can you tell that, pray?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Out of your own mouth you ſhall be judged. Miſs Neville, ſhe talked in her ſleep, like a beauty in a ſide box, and then fell a ſinging,

l.hi: No, no; he is true, and I believe;
He look'd, he ſigb'd, he can't deceive;
No, no; I have conquer'd; he is mine;
My heart is touch'd, and I reſign.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Oh! you ſcurrilous creature.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Fairly caught, Lady Jane.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: All odious ſlander; you judge of me by yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I do ſo. I mean to be married, and am frank enough to own it. But you may let "concealment feed on your damaſk cheek." My damaſk cheek, I hope, was made for other purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Gracious! there is no bearing this. What a mad girl you are!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt. A natural character. One would not, to be ſure, tell a hideous man that one loves him: but when one has encouraged him by degrees, and drawn him on, like a new glove, and perhaps done him a miſchief in the doing it, why then one would draw him off again, and may be aſk a pretty fellow to help a body; and then the wretch looks ſo piteous, and kneels at your feet, then riſes in a jealous fit. I take my everlaſting farewell; never to return; no, never; what to her? who encouraged me? encouraged him? who promiſed? broke her promiſe? The treacherous, faithleſs, dear deluding—then returns in an inſtant; hands dangling; eyes imploring; tongue faultering; Lady Bell, —Lady Bell—when you know that I adore you—And I burſt into a fit of laughter in his face: Oh! that's my joy, my triumph, my ſupreme delight.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And is not there a kind of cruelty in all this?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! your very humble ſervant, my ſweet Lady Graveairs. Cruelty! The difference between you and me, ſiſter, is this; you deny your love to your female friends, and own it to the man; now I deny it to him, but among ourſelves, I fairly own that Miſs Neville is not more impatient to be married to Sir Harry, than I to—

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Who, I? Spare me, I beg of you. Why Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Now, now, your turn is come. Never ſpare her, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Mſs NEV.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe me, I am not in ſpirits for all this raillery.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You ſhan't leave us.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Give me leave; I beg you will. I'll go and talk to Madam La Rouge. Perhaps I may ſucceed for you.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Well, if you muſt go.—How you run on, ſiſter! And are you really in love?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Over head and ears.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Not with Capt. Bygrove: how alarmed you are! With Millamour, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Fix that roving temper, if you can; he will be on his knees to you, and the firſt pair of black eyes that enters the room will be through his heart.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: As to that, I give myſelf very little trouble: but if I could once catch him paying his adoration to me, my aunt Bromley does not raiſe and ſink poor Miſs Neville's ſpirits with ſuch exquiſite ſkill in the art of tormenting, as I ſhould his. I ſhould uſe him as the men do their punch; a little more ſweet; a little more ſower; a little more ſpirit; more acid again; then perhaps ſay it's good for nothing, and then, perhaps—

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Sip it up at laſt, as you would do at firſt. You wicked girl, how could you aſk me ſuch a queſtion? Law! what am I about? I have a thouſand things to do.

div.stage: Enter Miſs NEVILLE, and Madam LA ROUGE.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Ah! my Lady! always ſo gay; Engliſh climate no effect upon you. De maniere de Paris for all de vorl. En verite, vous eſt charmante.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p:
Oh! Madam La Rouge, you ſay ſuch polite things; but you rob me of all my money.
My ſiſter is rich: you had better deal with her. Siſter, you'll be married before me.

div.stage: "No, no, he is true, and I believe, &c.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Was ever any thing ſo crazy?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: It is all vivacite! and, my Lady, you have ver great wit en partage; vous avez les graces! you have de grace; but you no deal vid me.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: I ſhall call at your houſe in Pall mall. Miſs Neville, you joined againſt me: I am very angry with you.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Madamoiſelle, I tell you; perſuade my Lady to have de lace, and you come to my houſe, me give you ver pretty preſent.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Oh! you have a national talent for applying a little bribery.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Diantre; 'tis falſe delicateſſe. You not know de manieres of the vorl.—Ah! Monſieur Malvil!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Madam La Rouge. I did not expect this pleaſure.

sp.speaker: La ROUGE.
sp.p: It is always pleaſure to ſee mes amis; to ſee my friends; and I glad to ſee you here vid de Lady. You have ver good choice. And I can tell you, make diſpatch: you have rival.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Rival?

sp.speaker: La ROUGE.
sp.p: You not know? Sir Harry have taſke as well as you. Madamoiſelle, you are ver great favourite.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: A favourite! keep your vivacity for ſome other ſubject: don't make me the town talk.

sp.speaker: La ROUGE.
sp.p: It is ver true: He come to my houſe in Pall-mall, and ſay ver fine ting of Madamoiſelle Neville, and Monſieur Daſh would praiſe you ver much.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Ay, his malice is at work.

sp.speaker: La ROUGE.
sp.p: Monſieur, you loſe all your time— (goes to him and ſpeaks low) You wait de fortune from Madam Bromley: Sir Harry vil take her vidout any money at all. Vat you ſlow for?

sp.speaker: MAD.
sp.p: Are the apartments kept ready at your houſe?

sp.speaker: La ROU.
sp.p: De apartment it is ready. You take it two, tree week ago, and pay de rent for noting— I leave you vid de lady; and I go mind mes affaires. Bon voyage.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I have diſengaged myſelf, to have the honour of attending you.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Your attention is thrown away. Did not I hear Mr. Millamour's voice?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Yes; he came with me; he is gone into the next room to pay his compliments to Lady Jane. I am ſorry to ſee him for ever diſtracted; always reſolving, and yet every day beginning the world over again. You look chagrin'd, what has diſturb'd you?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: The old ſtory; Mrs. Bromley's eternal whims.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: She is not ſpoken of as I could wiſh. Good natured and arrogant, generous and cruel, obliging and oppreſſive, at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: There cannot ſurely, be a more diſtreſsful ſituation than to remain under daily obligations, and yet not be able to eſteem our benefactreſs.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Your delicacy charms me: It has fixed me yours. I long for nothing ſo much, as to ſee you out of her power. They have a ſtrange report about town: people will be talking: the whiſper goes that Mr. Bygrove, amidſt all his grief, is ſlily in a hurry for another wife. Mrs. Bromley, they ſay, encourages him; and at the ſame time has a deſign upon my friend Millamour.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: The world is not always wrong.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Malice will be buſy; and does not ſpare the young ladies.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: If any thing is ſaid to their diſadvantage, believe me, they do not deſerve it.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I dare ſay not: I don't think they are too forward. I am ſorry to ſee, in one of the papers to-day, a character of Sir Harry, not at all favourable. His little follies, his whims, and caprices one does not mind: He may walk in Daſhwould's train as long as he pleaſes; that only makes him ridiculous. But it grieves me to hear that perfidy ſtains his character, and, as I am told, the worſt of perfidy: the ruin of beauty and innocence is his ruling paſſion.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: This is very odd: ſomebody has been at the trouble of ſending me an anonymous letter to that very effect: and why to me? I am not able to decypher.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I don't like anonymous letters. In general they aim at miſchief, but this perhaps, is meant as a caution to you: it muſt be a friend that ſent it.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: No; I can gueſs the quiver from whence that arrow comes.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Daſhwould, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I don't ſay that.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Nor I; I never-charge any body; but upon recollection, the letter in the news-paper is imputed to him. Mrs. Bromley, I know, has no opinion of Sir Harry. His deſigns, with regard to you, ſhe does not think honourable. My heart intereſts me for you. You know I am all heart. The plan which Mrs. Bromley has propoſed—Hark! I think I hear Millamour coming. I'll follow you up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Oh! Sir! you have frighten'd me out of my wits.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p:
She loves Sir Harry, I ſee; and yet ſhe ſhan't ſlip thro' my hands. I can ſet on Mrs. Bromley
to lead her a weary life, and if I can prevail upon Millamour to renounce Lady Bell, and marry the widow, my buſineſs is done. When Miſs Neville is heartily tormented by Mrs. Bromley, affliction ſoftens the mind, and I may then decoy her away, and ſtand upon terms with the family. But Daſhwould's wit will fly about. No matter: he is a ſad ſcoundrel, and does not mind how he murders reputations. So! here comes Millamour. I muſt get clear of him, and talk further with Miſs Neville.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: From this moment I blot all other woman from my memory. malvil, wiſh me joy. The perplexity of choice is now at an end.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Why, what has happen'd?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lovely Lady Jane. "And yield her charms of mind with ſweet delay."—I can't ſtay to tell you now.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Nor will I ſtay to interrupt your raptures. You know, I wiſh you ſucceſs.

l.hi: Who yields too ſoon, muſt ſoon her lover loſe:
Would you reſtrain him long? then long refuſe.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There is ſomething commanding in that air of vivacity.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: "Oft at your door let him for entrance wait, There let him"— How! Millamour here! how could you ſurprize me ſo? You horrid thing! how long have you been here?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Been, Madam?—I have been—I have been in the next room, paying my reſpects to your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And never enquired for poor Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip wrongs me. You doinjuſtice to your own charms: they can never beforgot.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I ſee how it is: the other day you was liſted in my ſervice, and now a deſerter to my ſiſter! you are right, you would have been upon hard duty with me.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Any duty but a forlorn hope would be—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Hope!—why ſure, you would not have had the intolerable aſſurance, to entertain the ſmalleſt degree of hope? My ſiſter, I ſuppoſe, has given you ſome hope. Ay! that's her way: She moves by ſettled rules, and ſhines with equal light. Now I—I am a mere comet, I blaze of a ſudden; dazzle for a while, then wheel away, and am thought of no more.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: That gaiety of her's is charming, (aſide) The impreſſion your ladyſhip makes—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Words; mere words;—No; I am a ſtrange piece of wild nature; never the ſame for two minutes together. Now, my ſiſter, ſhe is a Pruſſian blue, holds her colour, and is always the ſame.—I—I am a mere changeable ſilk—I ſhift about, and diſplay my wit, and my folly, ſo curiouſly blended, that no body can tell where one begins, or the other ends. I am not worth your notice.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She has deſcribed herſelf admirably; without variety, a woman is a downright piece of inſipidity.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Yes; I have my whims. Never the ſame for two minutes together. Now I love to give a ſcope to folly, and the men ſay, "curſe catch her, ſhe pleaſes more, when in the wrong, than other women when they are in the right. Then good ſenſe is the word; and the next moment I can't bear the fatigue of thinking; why won't ſomebody write a comedy to divert me? Then all ſpirit, and I long to lead up the ball.

l.hi: Ladies, like variegated tulips, ſhow
'Tis to their weakneſs all their charms they owe.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lade Jane is mere mediocrity compared to her.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Lord! I run on at a ſtrange rate. Yours, Mr. Millamour: Au revoir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: A moment longer: you muſt not leave me: You poſſeſs my heart: poſſeſs it without a rival.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Hey! what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Do not trifle with a paſſion ſincere as mine. I adore you, my Lady Bell; adore your matchleſs charms; thus on my knees adore.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay; let me ſee what the poet ſays,

l.hi: Oft at your door let him for entrance wait,
There let him kneel, and threaten and entreat.

sp.p: There, ſtay there; don't offer to ſtir. Now put up both your hands, and pray, pray, have compaſſion, Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: MILLAMOUR.
sp.l: She flies diſdainful from her lover's view,
Yet looks and bids him, as ſhe flies, purſue.

div.head: ACT the THIRD.
div.stage: Enter Lady JANE, and Capt. BYGROVE.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: AND laid his commands upon you to addreſs my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Moſt peremptorily.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You have obeyed him I hope.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p:
You know your power too well; you
know that I am devoted to you, and that my happineſs depends upon the promiſe you have made me.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: There, that is always the way with you men: our ſmiles, are ſure marks of approbation; and every civil thing we ſay, is conſtrued into a promiſe.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: And have not you promiſed?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Need I anſwer that queſtion? How eaſily frightened you are! but you have ſome reaſon to be alarmed. Millamour has been on his knees to me, breathing ſuch raptures—

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Ay!—who has ſet him on?—what can be at the bottom of this?—And have you liſtened to him?—Here comes Daſhwould; he perhaps can explain.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: He will only laugh at us; and ſo I'll make my eſcape.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Not to hear Millamour again, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Well, well to purchaſe my liberty, you need not fear. I have received his vows, delivered with ſuch ardour!—how terrified you look?—I have liſtened to him, to alarm my ſiſter with an idea of Millamour's growing paſſion for me. If her jealouſy is once touched, it may fix her reſolution. At preſent, ſhe is as volatile as Millamour himſelf.

sp.speaker: DASHW.
sp.p: As volatile as Millamour! what can that be? I never knew any thing that would bear a compariſon

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: What think you of my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: DASHW.
sp.p:
Lady Bell has her whims. I left her above ſtairs, in cloſe conference with Millamour; he has deſerted your Ladyſhip already. Mrs. Bromley will be the next, I hope: your father, would Captain,
would grieve more for that, than for his deceaſed wife.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And then Miſs Nevill's turn may come.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! no. To ſport with her would be inhumanity. But a briſk widow, is fair game.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Yes, and it may help to cure my father of his folly.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: It would be ſport, but I deſpair of it. You know, Mr. Daſhwould, you allow that Millamour has underſtanding.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: But he does not act from his underſtanding. Fits and ſtarts of paſſion govern him. If in any one purſuit of real uſe, he had half the alacrity of mind, with which he runs on, from one folly to another, he would be a man for the ladies to pull caps for. But he lives for ever in inconſiſtencies. One action of his life is the ſure forerunner of the contrary. Firſt Malvil is his favourite! then arm in arm with me: Can any two things be more oppoſite? It is the ſame among the ladies! they all have him by turns, and the whim of one moment, is ſure to find a ridiculous antitheſis in the next.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: He ſat for that picture, I'll ſwear.— Well, there's a gentleman wants your advice, and ſo I'll leave you together.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: My dear Daſhwould, you muſt aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What diſtreſſes you?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: My evil genius is at work. You know what my father has reſolved upon. Lady Bell is the perſon he chuſes for me.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I know all that buſineſs: a counterplot of the widow's fertile brain, to diſappoint Lady Bell, and wreak her malice on Millamour.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p:
But the malice falls on me only. Why will not Millamour know his own mind? Lady Bell
loves him; I know ſhe does. I am thwarted in the tendereſt point; what muſt be done?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Do as they would have you: you enſure ſucceſs. Millamour's jealouſy takes fire upon the firſt alarm, and while the paſſion holds, he will have vigour enough to act deciſively.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: May I hazard the Experiment?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: It's a ſure card. Take my advice.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley's coach has juſt ſtopp'd at the door: had not you better ſtep up ſtairs, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Daſhwould, you are abſent too long. They are all as dull as a funeral, above ſtairs.

sp.speaker: DASH. (Aſide to Capt. BYGROVE)
sp.p: How the Baronet follows Miſs Neville from room to room!—Come, Captain, I'll play a game of picquet with you before dinner.—Allons!

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: If I might have the liberty, ma'am, to—

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Another time, if you pleaſe, Sir Harry. Mrs. Bromley is coming: I hear her voice.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: And you promiſe me the hearing?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You are entitled to it, Sir. I beg you'll leave me now.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I obey your commands; I am gone; you'll remember.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes; and I think in good humour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p:
Oh! I am heartily tired. I have been paying viſits to people who have never been let
into my houſe, and who, I hope, will never be at home for me. I hate them all, but out of civility, we muſt keep up an acquaintance. Where are the girls? Has any body been here?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Mr. Millamour, ma'am, and the reſt of the gentlemen that dine here: they are all above ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Stupidity! did not I give orders— How long has Millamour been here?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: About an hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: With Lady Bell, I ſuppoſe— Thou baſe ingratitude! and Sir Harry is here too, I reckon. Does your match go on? You ſhall go back to the country, I promiſe you. You'll be the ruin of thoſe girls. They ſhall have no viſitors, when my back is turned. I'll give orders to all the ſervants this very moment.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: To ſee Mrs. Bromley looking ſo well—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You are very polite, Sir. Buſineſs calls me now, Sir John; I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Has my ſon been here to-day?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: He is above ſtairs with Lady Bell, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Miſs Neville, Neville, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You'll excuſe me, Sir John; what can ſhe want?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: This viſit portends ſome good, I hope. I ſhall be happy if he has declared himſelf. I'll ſtep and ſee what he 〈◊〉 about.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Exquiſite! lovely angel!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Well!—how!—what!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir; I am not at leiſure; I am in the third region; and can't deſcend to the language of the nether world.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Then you are in love, George.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She is a ſiſter of the Graces, and ſurpaſſes the other three. I am fixed; unalterably fixed; and am going about the marriage articles directly.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: They are at my lawyer's, ready engroſſed; and only wait for the lady's name, to fill up the blanks.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I know it, Sir; I muſt ſtep for them; I have it through my heart: I feel it here: I am your humble ſervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, do you ſtay here; I'll ſtep for Mr. Copyhold. The writings ſhall be here in ten minutes.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: The ſooner the better, Sir.

l.hi: Let thoſe love now, who never lov'd before;
Let thoſe who always lov'd, now love the more.

sp.p: Loll, tol, lol.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Bravo! you ſeem in prodigious ſpirits.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I am ſo: I am happy in myſelf, and happy in my friends, and happy in every circumſtance, and in tip-top ſpirits, and—my dear Malvil, your's down to the ground.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Methinks I ſympathize with you. When our friends are happy, the ſenſation is well called a fellow feeling.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p:
Malvil, I thank you: your turn of mind is formed for laſting friendſhips. With Daſhwould it is all diſſipation, and giddy mirth, the mere bubble of pleaſure. To you, I may talk ſeriouſly, The topic of the day is enough for Daſhwould. I can now tell you, that I ſhall be happy for life. But
for Daſhwould, I ſhould have been ſettled long ago. That fellow has led me into a thouſand errors.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: He has his admirers, and not without reaſon. He thinks me his enemy, but he is miſtaken. I never harbour reſentment.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You are growing grave, and I am a flight above common ſenſe at preſent.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Daſhwould, notwithſtanding all his faults, does hit the mark ſometimes. I don't uſually laugh at his pleaſantry; I don't like to encourage him too much; but it muſt be owned, he is often right. Behind his back I cannot help being diverted by him. He has a quick inſight into characters.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No want of penetration there.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: No, no; he ſays, and perhaps rightly, your lively ladies often want common prudence; and giddy in the purſuit of pleaſure, they are frequently miſerable in the end.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: But Lady Bell's good ſenſe, that refinement of underſtanding—

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: There are falſe refinements; the ſhadow for the ſubſtance. Who is it that obſerves, we all diſcover early ſymptoms of the diſeaſe, by which our minds and bodies go to ruin?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Po! with Lady Bell there can be no riſk.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I don't know whether Daſhwould is good authority.—You know him beſt. He ſays—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: He is a ſhrewd obſerver.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Nobody more ſo.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: If he has a regard for any body, it is for you. You are the only man I never heard him ſpeak ill of. A match with Lady Bell is not to his mind. He talk'd ſeriouſly on the ſubject. Has not he told you?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I wonder at that. Lady Bell, he ſays, ſhew'd herſelf early. Impatient of advice, attentive to nothing but her beauty! whole days at her looking glaſs—I repeat his very words—he ſeemed to ſpeak out of downright regard for you.—At her toilette every feature had its inſtructions how to look; but no inſtruction for the mind. And then, ſays he, that terrible love of gaming!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Gaming!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Don't you know it? I can't ſay I ever ſaw it myſelf. Time will determine her character.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If ſhe loves gaming, it is pretty well determined already.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Perhaps not: I ſtill hope for the beſt.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Why yes; a man of ſenſe may form her mind, and then the gentler affections may take their turn.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The very thing I ſaid.—But our pleaſant friend had an anſwer ready—Gentle affections, ſays he! don't you ſee that it is with people that once love play, as with perſons addicted to ſtrong cordials? they never return to cooler liquors.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Thereis ſome truth in that. I am for ever obliged to you. It is ingenuous, it is friendly in you to convey the hint.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Don't build too much upon it. I have told you my author; and you know his way: he may deny it all.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Shall I talk to him?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay to that. In his vein of pleaſantry, he may give it another turn.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: He may ſo. I am glad to know all this. But my Lady Jane, there's a model for her ſex to imitate.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p:
Have you watch'd her well? People ſhould appear what they really are. Let a precipice look like a precipice. When covered over with flowers,
it only ſerves to deceive the unwary. Mrs. Bromley has been very communicative about Lady Jane.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You alarm me. My dear friend explain.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: To do Lady Bell juſtice, ſhe is above diſguiſe. And though ſhe has her faults, I have ſeen her pleaſe by thoſe very faults.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And ſo have I. Her very blemiſhes are beauty ſpots.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: No frankneſs about the youngeſt girl. It is friendſhip for you that makes me ſpeak. Her character is all forced, ſtudied, put on with her rouge.

sp.speaker: MIL.
