sp.p: Does ſhe paint?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: A little; the prudent touch. I am ſorry for her. When ſhe is ſettled in the world, many qualities, which now lie concealed, will break out into open day-light.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: What a maſked battery there will be to play off upon her huſband!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Their aunt told me all in confidence. You may judge how painful it is to her. I have known the family for ſome time. I can't but be ſorry for the young ladies.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And ſince this is the caſe, I don't care how little I know of them, or their family.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: No occaſion to quarrel with the family. Great merit about Mrs. Bromley. She made an admirable wife, and that at an early period. She was but ſeventeen when ſhe married.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No more?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Not an hour: ſhe is not thirty: an eſtate in her own right, and the command of half a borough. No oppoſition there; the old houſes have the votes. A man may get a ſeat without trouble. Does not Sir John want to ſee you in parliament?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes. It would give him pleaſure.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Well, you will judge for yourſelf. Were I as you, I ſhould know what courſe to take. Here ſhe comes! a good fine woman! a man may there ſit down to his happineſs at once.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Mr. Millamour, (curtſies) Mr. Malvil, what have you done with Mr. Bygrove?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I parted with him where you ſet us down. (ſpeaks to ber aſide) I have talked to Millamour, and I think it will do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Go you up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: How charmingly you look! like Lady Bell's eldeſt Siſter!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Po! you are laughing at me.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Not I truly: I appeal to Millamour. I'll take the liberty to join the company above. (aſide to Millamour) She is the beſt of the family.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: A valuable man Mr. Malvil is! He has a great eſteem for you, Sir. His ſincerity is unequall'd. You ſeem thoughtful, Mr. Millamour.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Thoughtful, Ma'am!—There are certain ſubjects that—what Malvil ſays is true—A man may marry her, and ſit down to his happineſs at once

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Sir John has been ſaying a great deal to me about you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Has he, Ma'am!—There is a circumſtance, which he is as yet a ſtranger to—a circumſtance, which to communicate, will perhaps—It is what I have long wiſhed, and—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Faultering! heſitating! (aſide) I interrupt you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There is a circumſtance, Ma'am—the affair is—My father for a long time—Sir John, for a long time—Sir John has wiſhed—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: To ſee you married?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: To ſee me married, Ma'am—and—he has —he has wiſhed it much.—And a ſettlement, by way of jointure—long ready for the lady's name—that is—any lady, who ſhall honour me with her affection —and—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: No lady can be inſenſible of your pretenſions.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You are very good, Ma'am; and after long obſervation, and a laſting paſſion grafted on it, which, tho' ſilent hitherto, —yet working ſecretly—when diſcloſed at length—may to the perſon in the world— who already formed by experience, may in every reſpect —and if without preſuming too far—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: What a delicate confuſion he is in.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And if this paper, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: When given by you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Perverſe and cruel!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You both look grave; nothing amiſs, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Every thing is as it ſhould be, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Not if he knew all.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Sir John has been complaining—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Paſs that by; adviſe your own ſon; had not you better ſtep up ſtairs? Mr. Millamour will do what is right. (ſiniling at him) You may leave it all to him; truſt to his judgment.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Millamour, I have ſuch a ſtory for you: Malvil and Daſhwould have been quarrelling about you, and—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po! and here they all come; I knew the ſubſtance could not be far off, when the ſhadow projected before it.

div.stage: Enter Lady BELL, DASHWOULD, and MALVIL.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Mr. Daſhwould, do you think I'll bear this? What liberty will you take next? You think, becauſe I laugh, that I am not offended.— Aunt, I received a letter, and he has attempted to ſnatch it from me.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Why it brings a little cargo of ridicule from the country, and my friend Malvil ſees no joke in it.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: When my friend's name is brought in queſtion, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: It is diverting notwithſtanding.— Aunt, what do you think? My Couſin Cynthia, you know, was to be married to Sir George Squanderſtock; her mother oppoſed it, and broke off the match, and now it's come out, that ſhe was all the time the clandeſtine rival of her own daughter.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Not inapplicable to the preſent buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Go, you giddy girl, no ſuch thing!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She charms by her very faults.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR. (goes up to BYGROVE)
sp.p: And Daſhwould has been ſaying—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Po! repeat none of his ſayings to me.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Did you ſay any thing, Mr. Daſhwould? What was it?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! nothing. Sir George Squanderſtock is my very good friend.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: And for that reaſon you might ſpare him No man is without his faults.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Ay, allow him faults, out of tenderneſs.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Sir George is a valuable man, Sir, and repreſents his county to great advantage.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He does ſo; takes a world of pains; nothing can eſcape him; Manilla ranſom not paid; there muſt be a motion about that matter: he knots his handkerchief to remember it.—Scarcity of corn! another knot—triennial parliaments— (knots) Juries Judges of law as well as fact (knots) national debt (knots) bail in criminal caſes (knots) and ſo on he goes, till his handkerchief is twiſted into queſtions of ſtate; the liberties and fortunes of all poſterity dangling like a bede roll; he puts it in his pocket, drives to the gaming table, and the next morning his handkerchief goes to the waſh, and his country and the minority are both left in the ſuds.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: What a deſcription!

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Hey! lively Lady Bell!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Ho! ho! I thank you, Daſhwould.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM. (aſide to Millamour)
sp.p: How can you encourage him? Let us leave 'em to themſelves.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You ſee, Mr. Bygrove—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Ay! thus he gets a ſtory to graft his malice upon, and then he ſets the table in a roar at the next tavern.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Never be out of humour with Daſhwould, Mr. Bygrove; he keeps me alive; he has been exhibiting pictures of this ſort all the morning, as we rambled about the town.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! no; no pictures; I have ſhewn him real life.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Very true, Daſhwould: and now mind him: he will touch them off to the life for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Millamour ſo cloſe with Lady Bell! the forward importunity of that girl.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
There is poſitively no ſuch thing as going about this town, without ſeeing enough to ſplit your
ſides with laughing. We called upon my friend Sir Volatile Vainlove: he, you know, ſhines in all polite aſſemblies, and is, if you believe himſelf, of the firſt character for intrigue. We found him drinking Valerian tea for his breakfaſt, and putting on falſe calves.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: And the confuſion he was in, when we entered the room!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: In the next ſtreet, we found Jack Spinbrain, a celebrated poet, with a kept miſtreſs at his elbow, writing lampoons for the news-paper; one moment murdering the reputation of his neighbours, and the next a ſuicide of his own.—We ſaw a young heir, not yet of age, granting annuity bonds, and five Jews and three Chriſtians, duped by their avarice to lend money upon them. A lawyer—

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Hear, hear; it is all true. I was with him.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A lawyer taking notes upon Shakeſpeare: a deaf Nabob raviſhed with muſic, and a blind one buying pictures. Men without talents, riſing to preferment, and real genius going to a jail.—An officer in a marching regiment with a black eye, and a French hair-dreſſer wounded in the ſword arm.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! by this light I can vouch for every word.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Go on, Sir Harry, ape your friend in all his follies; be the nimble marmozet; grin at his tricks, and try to play them over again yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Well now, that is too ſevere: Daſhwould, defend me from his wit. You know I hoard up all your good things.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You never pay me in my own coin, Sir Harry: try now; who knows but you will ſay ſomething?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Friend or foe it is all alike.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And where is the mighty harm? I like pulling to pieces of all things.

sp.speaker: MIL. (following Lady BILL.)
sp.p:
To be ſure it is the
life of converſation. Does your Ladyſhip know Sir George Squanderſtock's ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I have ſeen her.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She is a politician in petticoats; a fierce republican; ſhe talks of the dagger of Brutus, while ſhe ſettles a pin in her tucker; and ſays more about ſhip money, than pin-money.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And now you muſt turn buſſoon?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I know the lady; ſhe ſcolds at the loyaliſts, goſſips againſt the act of ſettlement, and has the fidgets for magna charta.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She encourages a wrinkle againſt bribery; flirts her fan at the miniſtry, and bites her lips at taxes, and a ſtanding army.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mr. BYCROVE, will you bear all this?

div.stage: Enter Miſs NEVILLE, and whiſpers Mrs. BROMLEY.

sp.speaker: Mrs Brom.
sp.p: Very well, Neville, I'll come preſently.

sp.speaker: MAL. (looking at Miſs Neville.)
sp.p: I ſhall ſtay no longer. Mr. Bygrove, will you walk?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No, Sir, I ſhall not leave the enemy in this room behind me: a bad tranſlator of an antient poet, is not ſo ſure to deface his original, as his licentious ſtrain to diſparage every character.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Sir Harry, he will neither give, nor take a joke.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: No, I told you ſo.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Let me tell you once for all, Sir—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I wiſh you would.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Why interrupt? Do you know what I was going to ſay?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: No, do you?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I'll leave 'em all to themſelves.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Millamour gone!

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p:
Let me tell you, Sir, with all your flaſhes of wit, you will find that you have been playing with an edge-tool at laſt. And what does this mighty witamount
to? The wit in vogue, expoſes one man; makes another expoſe himſelf; gets into the ſecrets of an intimate acquaintance, and publiſhes a ſtory to the world; belies a friend; puts an anecdote, a letter, an epigram into the news-paper; and that is the whole amount of modern wit.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A ſtrain of moroſe invective is more diverting, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: BYG. (looking about for Mrs. Bromley.)
sp.p: Well, Sir, we'll adjourn the debate. You may go on; miſrepreſent every thing; if there is nothing ridiculous, invent a ſtory: and when you have done it, it is but a cheap and a frivolous talent. Has a lady a good natural bloom? Her paint muſt be an expenſive article. Does ſhe look grave? She will ſin the deeper. Is ſhe gay and affable? Her true character will come out at the Commons. That is the whole of your art, and I leave you to the practice of it.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Satyrical Bygrove! now the widow has him in tow.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Could not you ſtay till my back was fairly turned?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What a look there was!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: At what a rate you run on! you keep the field againſt them all.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Sir Harry, ſtep up, and watch him with the widow.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I will; don't ſtay too long.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I'll follow you: and hark, make your party good with Miſs Neville.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: You ſee, Lady Belt, a ſling at every body.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The Baronet does not want parts; that is to ſay, he has very good materials to play the fool with. I ſhall get him to marry Miſs Neville.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Bring that about, and you will for once do a ſerious action, for which every body will honour you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: In the mean time, do you watch your aunt Bromley: ſhe is your rival.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Rival? That would be charming!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: It is even ſo. Now Millamour's underſtanding is good, but his paſſions quick: if you play your cards right—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Are you going to teach me how to manage a man?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Coquettry will never ſucceed with him. A quickſand does not ſhift ſo often as his temper. You muſt take him at his word, and never give him time to change, and veer about.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Totally out of nature.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! very well. I give up the point.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You may leave the man to my management. My aunt Bromley rival me! that would be delightful.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Well, ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Can you be ſerious for a moment?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Well, the ſolemnity of that look! Muſt I ſet my face by yours, and contract a wrinkle, by a formal oeconomy of features, which you, like the reſt of the world, miſtake for wiſdom?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Will you hear me? They are hurrying this match too faſt, I think. Sir John is come, and his lawyer is expected every moment. He wants to conclude the affair this day, and my aunt does not oppoſe it. But I don't like all this hurry.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And why need you be concerned about it?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Do you think Millamour capable of love?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: For the moment. It will be difficult to fix him.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Do?—Nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE,
sp.p: How ſilly! you know it is not my ſeeking.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: What are you about? Talking in your ſleep again? Lady Jane, wake yourſelf. What have you taken into your head?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Why ſince Mr. Millamour has prevailed with me—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: His affections then are fixed upon you?—Why the man has been dying at my feet, with a face as rueful as a love elegy.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You will permit me to laugh in my turn.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! I can laugh with you, and at you, and at him too. This gives ſpirit to the buſineſs: here are difficulties, and difficulties enhance victory, and victory is triumph.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Very well! oh! brave! laugh away! you will be undeceived preſently.—If this does not take, I am at the end of my line.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: What does all this mean? Rivall'd, outwitted by my ſiſter! Inſupportable! This begins to grow ſerious.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! ſhe here! Sir John is quite impatient, and I am going for his attorney.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And Lady Jane is impatient too: ſhe is the object of your choice.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lady Jane! you are pleaſant, very pleaſant!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: She has told me with inflexible gravity!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She is a great wit; and great wits have great quickneſs of invention; and ſo a ſtory is eaſily dreſſed up. I could crack my ſides with laughing. If trifling civilities have been received as a declaration of love—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And is that the caſe? Very whimſical indeed!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, very whimſical! I am eternally yours, ma'am, and I am on the wing, and your Ladyſhip's adorer.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Now to plague 'em both.— Siſter, you may hear it from himſelf.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: That lady, Sir, has the ſtrangeſt notion.—

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You will be ſo good as to explain all to my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Both upon me at once.—I have explained, madam, and all further talk about it is unneceſſary.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Only to ſatisfy her curioſity.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: To ſhew my ſiſter her miſtake.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I have made every thing clear, ma'am.— (to Lady Bell) Have not I, Lady Bell? And— (turns to Lady Jane) every thing now is upon a proper footing.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Very well; only give her to underſtand—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Your underſtanding is admirable. (turns to Lady Bell) I told you ſhe would talk in this ſtyle. (turns to Lady Jane) You are perfectly right, and nobody underſtands things better. (turns to Lady Bell) Nobody whatever.
sp.stage: (looks and laughs at both by turns)

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: But give me leave. You muſt ſpeak out, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Never argue about it, it is not worth your while.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: There is ſome myſtery in all this.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No; all very clear: (to Lady Jane) drop it for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: But I deſire no doubt may remain.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And I don't like to be kept in ſuſpenſe.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Diſtraction! I am like a lawyer, that has taken fees on both ſides. You do me honour, ladies; but upon my ſoul, I can't help laughing. It will divert us ſome day or other, this will. Oh! ho! ho! I ſhall die with laughing.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. BROMLEY, and Sir JOHN.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: What is all this uproar for?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Another witneſs of my folly!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Millamour, I give you joy: Mr. Copyhold, your attorney, is come with the deeds. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: The ſtrangeſt adventure! I can't ſtay now. The ladies have been very pleaſant. You love humour, and they have an infinite deal. I'll come to you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: George, don't run away: let us finiſh the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: If he ſays he'll marry, you may depend upon him. A poet, determined to write no more, or a gameſter forſwearing play, is not ſo ſure to keep his word. I wiſh I may die, if I don't think him as much to be relied upon as a prime miniſter.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Aunt? Would you believe it? The demure Lady Jane— (burſts into a laugh) She has taken ſuch a fancy into her head! Millamour ſhe thinks is up to the eyes in love with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! poor Lady Jane!

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And my ſiſter's pride is hurt. She carries it with an air, as if ſhe had made a complete conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: How ridiculous the girls are! your ſon has open'd his mind to you, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: He has, and I approve of his choice. I hope it is as agreeable to you, as to his father.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I don't know how to refuſe my conſent.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: What does all this mean?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: As I could wiſh, There he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Since it has your approbation, Sir John, I believe I muſt yield my conſent. I never thought to marry again, but ſince you will have it ſo—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Lady Bell I underſtand, is willing to do me the honour of being my daughter in law.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! ho! this makes amends for all. My dear Aunt Bromley, are you impoſed upon? Did you liſten to the traitor's vows?— The dear, perfidious?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He will ſoon be ſettled, Sir John, ſince there are now three rival goddeſſes contending for him. Mr. Bygrove, you are come in good time.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: What fool's part are you to play now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Sir John, I deſire I may not be made your ſport. Have not I here, under his hand, a declaration of his mind; here, in this copy of verſes, given to me by himſelf, an earneſt of his affection?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Verſes! Aunt?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Verſes to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Verſes to me: only hear, Sir John.

l.hi: "I look'd, and I ſigh'd, and I wiſh'd I could ſpeak,"
"And ſain would have paid adoration.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay; mine begin the ſame way:

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: The very words of mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Will thoſe girls have done?

p.hi: "But when I endeavour'd the matter to break,"
"Still then I ſaid leaſt of my paſſion."

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Will you be quiet?

l.hi: "Still then I ſaid leaſt of my paſſion;"

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: "And reſolv'd I would try.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROMLEY, and Lady BELL, (reading together.

p.hi: "Some way my poor heart to recover."

sp.speaker: Lady JANE, Lady BELL, and Mrs. BROMLEY. (reading eagerly together).

l.hi: "But that was all vain, for I ſooner could die,
"Than live with forbearing to love her.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! ho! Mr. Daſhwould, what a piece of work has he made?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And the verſes copied from Congreve.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Copied from Congreve!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: There, Sir John, there is your ſon's behaviour!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: There, Mr. Bygrove, there is the widow's behaviour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And now, Mr. Daſhwould, now for your wit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROMLEY. (to Sir JOHN.)
sp.p: I am not diſappointed in the leaſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: I never was ſo cover'd with confuſion!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I never was ſo diverted in all my days.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He has acted with great propriety upon the occaſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p:
He has made himſelf very ridiculous.
He has expoſed nobody but himſelf. Contempt is the only paſſion he can excite. A crazy, mad, abſurd—

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: An inconſtant, wild, irreſolute—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ſo whimſical a character.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: This behaviour will give him prodigious luſtre. He will ſhine after this. I hope his viſits will ceaſe at this houſe.

sp.speaker: BYG. (going up to Mrs. BROMLEY.)
sp.p: If ever you marry again, ſimilitude of temper muſt do it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Diſtraction! muſt you plague me too?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You have appear'd with an air, but it was all ſtruggling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: I cannot bear this.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Heavens knows how you have ſtruggled!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: And you too? (mimicks him) "A march in your family has diverted me of late." I renounce you all. Come, Lady Bell, Lady Jane, let us leave them to themſelves.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: You would not believe me, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL
sp.p: Oh! this to me is as good as a comedy.

sp.speaker: DASH. (to BYGROVE.)
sp.p: What ſhall I give you for your chance?

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: More than I'll give you for your wit. And there's your anſwer.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The old pike is hooked, and ſtruggles ſtill at the end of her line.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Mr. Daſhwould, ſpeak to this ſilly young man. You have influence over him. Keep him to dinner. You will for ever oblige me. I muſt go and pacify the ladies.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Poor Millamour! Dryden has painted him to a hair.
sp.l: Bleſt madman, who can every hour employ,
With ſomething new to wiſh, or to enjoy.

div.head: ACT the FOURTH.

sp.speaker: DASHWOULD.
sp.p: THIS way, Sir Harry. While they are all engaged in the pleaſures of the table, I want a word with you in private.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: With that face of importance! what is coming now?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Liſten to me: know a little of the ſubject before you give your opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I am all attention.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Did you mark Miſs Neville, at dinner?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: You know I did. And when Mrs. Bromley railed at her—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: She railed at her with a littleneſs of ſpirit, that diſgraced wealth and affluence, and gave to poverty the ſuperior character. You muſt have ſeen in the behaviour of that girl, though treated with pride and arrogance, a propriety that was elegant, and went even further; it intereſted every heart for her. She is the beſt of the group. Were I, at the head of ſuch a fortune as yours, to chooſe a wife, ſhe ſhould be the object of my affection.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: You have ſome ſcheme in all this.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I have; to ſerve you. I ſhould mortify the pride of Mrs. Bromley, by placing a valuable, but helpleſs, young lady upon a level with her at once.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: This is to end in ſome joke.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Wait for the wit before you laugh. I am in ſerious earneſt. Her underſtanding is the beſt among them. The others are all artificial; ſhe is a natural character; and if I am not miſtaken, has a heart. If I wanted heirs to my eſtate, ſhe ſhould be the mother of my children.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Were I to be the dupe of all this, how you would laugh at me? Ha! ha! ha! I know you too well.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Again! laughing without the provocation of a joke. Don't be the dupe of your own cunning. I know you love her; and will it not be a generoſity worthy of you, to extricate merit out of diſtreſs? Nay, the merit which you admire? The merit which would do honour to the choice of any man in England?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Well, I cannot contain.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: The ſcrape in which you involved Millamour with the widow!

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Fooliſh! that was Malvil's doing. You'll hear more of it by and by. There is an underplot in all his actions. I adviſe you for the beſt. Here is a lady in queſtion, untainted by the faſhions of the age. Make her your own. She has no fortune; what then? Shew yourſelf ſuperior to the ſordid views, that govern the little mercenary ſpirits of the world.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I have juſt recollected what you ſaid of Jack Invoice, upon his marriage.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
Jack Invoice! He never was intended for any thing but to be laughed at. Upon the death of a rich uncle in the city, he comes to the weſt end of the town, with a plumb in his pocket, and not an idea in his head; marries a fantaſtical woman of rank, and with a ſovereign contempt of all his former acquaintance, mixes with lords and people of quality,
who win his money, and throw his wig in the fire to divert themſelves. He laughs at their wit, and thinks himſelf in good company.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Admirable! you have him to a hair.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Hey! the picture is like.— (laughs)—Pretty well, is not it?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! the very thing! poor Jack Invoice! you have hunted him down.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Have I? (laughs) Yes, I think I have been pleaſant upon him. But come; to our point: in marrying Miſs Neville, there is nothing ridiculous. You like her, that's clear.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: But ſhe does not like me, and that's as clear. Somebody has done me a prejudice there. She received this letter, and gave it me to read.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: "To Miſs Neville— (opens it) Without a name?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: A poiſon'd arrow in the dark.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Anonymous letters are generally the effect of clandeſtine malice; this comes from a friend. If your honour, your virtue, and your peace of mind, are worth your care, avoid the acquaintance of Sir Harry. He is the deceiver of innocence, and means to add your name to the liſt of thoſe whom his treachery has already ruined. Make uſe of this hint, and act accordingly.—A pretty epiſtle— (pauſes) Don't I know this hand?— So, ſo! I underſtand it: I can trace this: ſay no more, Sir Harry: purſue Miſs Neville the cloſer for this. Will you let ſuch a fellow as Malvil, rob you of a treaſure?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: You don't ſuſpect him?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Leave it all to me. Aſſure Miſs Neville that this ſhall be cleared up. Huſh! we are interrupted: go and join the company.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Pſhaw! pox! the company without you—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Very well; leave me now: (Exit Sir Harry) What's the matter, Malvil?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It will be over preſently: a ſudden ſenſation; I can't bear to ſee others made unhappy. Mrs. Bromley is a very valuable woman, but at times rather violent.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And that's much to be lamented, is not it?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You may laugh at it, Sir, but I think it a ſerious matter. I left poor Miſs Neville in a flood of tears; and—here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Not riſing from table ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Excuſe me, Sir, I had rather not ſtay.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Never mind Mrs. Bromley's humours; come, we will all take your part.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I am not fit for company, Sir.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I am ſorry to loſe you: I'll leave you with my worthy friend; he will adminiſter conſolation.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch inhuman tyranny? Inſulted before the whole company!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It hurts me to the quick. I could not have believed her capable of ſuch violence.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You ſaw that I gave her no provocation.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It pains me to ſee what I do.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: She breaks out in ſuch paſſionate onſets, and never conſiders that an overbearing pride is the worſt of cruelty to an ingenuous mind.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p:
There are few who know how to confer an obligation. A diſintereſted action gives ſuch moments of inward pleaſure! Oh! there are moments of the heart, worth all the giddy pleaſures of life.
One benevolent action pays ſo amply, and yields ſuch exquiſite intereſt, that I wonder people are not fond of laying out their money in that way.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: During the whole time of dinner, it was one continued invective againſt me.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Millamour's behaviour had diſconcerted her. But that is no excuſe. Goodneſs by fits, and generoſity out of mere whim, can never conſtitute a valuable character. I am ſorry to ſee you ſo afflicted.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You are very good, Sir.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: No, I have no merit in it; the inſtincts of my nature leave me no choice. I have ſtudied myſelf, and I find I am only good by inſtict. I am ſtrangely intereſted for you. I have thought much of your ſituation: our time is ſhort; they will be all riſing from table, preſently. Attend to what I ſay: ſince Mrs. Bromley is ſo inceſſant in her tyranny, do as I already hinted to you. Withdraw from this houſe at once. Madam la Rouge has an apartment ready for you. You may there remain concealed. In the mean time I ſhall be at work for you. I ſhall prevail upon Mrs. Bromley to keep her word, about the five thouſand pounds. That added to what is in my power, will make a handſome ſettlement for you.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You heard what ſhe ſaid to Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: She wants to drive you to ſome act of deſpair; perhaps to give you up a ſacrifice to Sir Harry's looſe deſires.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Are you ſo clear about Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Sdeath! I ſee ſhe loves him.—Hereafter I will open a ſcene to aſtoniſh you. (pauſes, and looks at her) You can never be happy under this roof. Mrs. Bromley will make this quarrel up, I know ſhe will. The whole of her virtue conſiſts in repentance, but what kind of repentance? A ſpecious promiſe to reform her conduct, and a certain return of the ſame vices.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: She has made me deſperate. I can ſtay here no longer. I'll go back to the country. I ſhall there be at peace.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You will be there too much out of the way. When you are ſettled at Madam La Rouge's, the haughty Mrs. Bromley will ſee to what ſhe has driven you, and for the ſake of her character, will begin to relent. Sir Harry muſt not know where you are. He means your ruin, I am ſorry to ſay it, but I can give you ſuch convincing proof.—

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: BROM. Do you go to your room, madam; let me ſee you no more to-day.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It was a mere unguarded word that fell from Miſs Neville. (ſpeaks to Mrs. Bromley aſide) Millamour is aſhamed of his conduct, He is under my influence ſtill: I ſhall mould him to your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: BROM. (aſide to him) I am a fool to think any more about him. Go to him; watch him all day; you will not find me ungrateful. (loud) And pray tell thoſe girls to come up ſtairs. (Exit Malvil) Mighty well, madam. (to Miſs Neville) You muſt ſit next to Sir Harry: You have pretenſions, have you? And you muſt vouch for Lady Bell too? She does not love gaming; that ſtory is all calumny: beſpeak yourſelf a place in the ſtage coach; you ſhall quit this houſe, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: It will be the laſt time I ſhall receive thoſe orders, madam. Your favours are ſo embittered; there is ſuch a leaven of pride, even in your acts of bounty, that I cannot wiſh to be under any further obligations. If doing juſtice to Lady Bell, if avowing my ſentiments in the cauſe of ſo amiable a friend, can give you umbrage, I am not fit to remain in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: O brave! you ſhall travel. Give her a fortune! No, let Lady Bell reward her. How! —Millamour, as I live.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Deliver me, fate! ſhe here:—Madam— I—I—I—you are not going to leave us, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mirs. BROM. (ſmiling at Millamour)
sp.p: And how can you look me in the face?

sp.speaker: MIL. (ſeeing Sir JOHN)
sp.p: I am glad you are come, Sir, I wanted to—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Perverſe! what brings Sir John? (aſide)—I ſhall expect you above ſtairs, gentlemen. I muſt try once more to fix that irreſolute, inconſtant man.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: What a day's work have you made here?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Can you expect any good from all this? Ever doing and undoing! Theſe proceedings are terrible to your father.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You know, Sir, that to gratify you is the height of my ambition.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: For ſhame! don't imagine that you can deceive me any longer. Are you to be for ever in ſuſpence? Always reſolving, and yet never decided? Never knowing your own mind for five minutes?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I have not been haſty to determine.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: My indulgence has made me too ridiculous. You will force me to tell you my mind in harſher terms than I ever thought I ſhould have occaſion to do.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: What has happened to-day, was but a mere frolic, and it has all paſſed off in a little raillery.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And do you think that ſufficient? While you remain inſenſible of your folly; transferring your inclinations from one object to another; hurried away by every caſualty, you will prove the jeſt of all your acquaintance. You will ceaſe to live, before you have begun.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: This is rather too much, Sir. If I have, in a few inſtances, departed from a reſolution that ſeemed fixed, you know very well, it is not uncommon; and when a perſon means an extraordinary leap, he retires back, to take advantage of the ground, and ſpring forward with greater vigour.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: And thus you amuſe yourſelf, compounding upon eaſy terms, for the folly of every hour. There is no relying upon you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: After all, Sir, it is the prudent part to conſider every thing. The ladies were rather haſty in their concluſion. In our moments of reflection, as objects paſs before us, opinion will wear different colours.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: The very cameleon has that merit: but is there to be nothing inward? No ſelf-governing principle? A ſhip without a pilot, without rudder, or compaſs, is as likely to avoid rocks, and quickſands, as you to ſteer clear of ruin.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You ſeem exaſperated, but I really don't ſee the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: No?—Can't you feel how abſurd it is to be always beginning the world? Forever in a doubt? Day after day embarking in new projects, nay twenty different projects in one day, and often in an hour?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Spare my confuſion: I feel my folly; I feel it all; and let my future conduct.—

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: George, can I take your word? I know you have been at the gaming table.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: The gaming table !

sp.speaker: Sir JOHN.
sp.p: Say no more: I know it all: after the indulgence I have ſhewn you, I now ſee that my hopes are all to be diſappointed. If you have a mind to attone for what is paſt, purſue one certain plan, and be ſomebody. The time now opens a new ſcene, and calls for other manners. Reform your conduct, and I ſhall be happy. But I am tired of this eternal levity: my patience is wore out. I ſhall ſtay no longer in this houſe to be a witneſs of your abſurdity.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I have made myſelf very ridiculous here. I can't ſhew my face any more in this family. I'll go back to the Temple, and not marry theſe ten years. The law leads to great things: a ſeat in Parliament, a vote or two againſt your conſcience, a ſilk gown, and a judge; that's the courſe of things. I'll purſue my ambition.—Honeſt friend, (calls to a ſervant) hiſt! honeſt friend, will you be ſo good as juſt to get my hat?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: No, I bar hats. What, going to deſert us? The ſport is but juſt beginning. Bygrove has been lecturing his ſon, and quarreling with Malvil. The integrity of that honeſt gentleman is ſuſpected at laſt. He was the worthieſt man in the world this morning, as good a creature as ever was born, but now he has ſold himſelf to the widow. Lady Bell has been lively upon the occaſion; and Malvil, to ſupport his ſpirits, has plyed the Burgundy, till he looks the very picture of hypocriſy, with a ruddy complexion, and a ſparkling eye.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You may divert yourſelf, Sir; I have done with them all.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
But I can't part with you: you ſhall join us; Malvil ſhall have no quarter: he will ſtick to
his glaſs till his charity for his neighbour begins to ſtagger; then off drops the maſk: he will have courage enough to rail at mankind, and his true character will come forth, like letters in lemon juice before the fire.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Po! abſurd! I am on the rack. Why did you force me to ſtay dinner? I have been ſo weak, ſo frivolous.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: How ſo? Becauſe you chang'd your mind? There is nothing more natural. Don't you ſee men doing the ſame thing every day? Down goes the old manſion; a new one riſes; exotic trees ſmile on the landſcape, and enjoy the northern air; and when the whole is finiſhed, in less than a twelve-month, the auctioneer mounts his pulpit. "Pleaſing contiguity" —"Beautiful, and pictureſque ſcene"—"Delectably featured by Nature"—"Shall I ſay twenty thouſand?—Down it goes to the higheſt bidder, who pays his money, and runs away the next morning with an opera ſinger to Italy.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Why, yes, we ſee theſe things every day.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: No doubt; men are fickle, and inconſtant

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Very true; it is the way through life; in the loweſt rank, as well as the higheſt. You ſhan't ſee a journeyman Weaver, but he has his diſguſt, like a Lord, and changes his lodging, his houſe of call, his barber, and his field preacher.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Certainly; and then there is a real charm in variety. Beſides what you did to day, was a mere frolic.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Nothing more: and that fellow, Malvil, was the occaſion of it. My heart never rightly warmed to that man. I ſhall never conſult him again. Affairs were in a right train, if he had not interpoſed.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p:
You ſhall have your revenge. I have a mine to ſpring will blow him up— (laughs) His advice
to-day has ſerved to produce the widow's character.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, it has given a diſplay of her. (laughs) How could ſhe think me in earneſt? Marry her! I would go into the army ſooner.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A good pretty trade, the army: if you are killed in battle, it is your affair; if you conquer, you may retire, and live very prettily upon half pay.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Very true: the law is a more certain road.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: A good agreeable life the law is: for ever entangled in the cobwebs of Weſtminſter-hall; and you help to ſpin them yourſelf into the bargin.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And at the end of twenty years, you are thought a good promiſing young man.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: In the mean time you are conſtantly hiring out your lungs, and ever in a paſſion about other people's affairs.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And travelling circuits, in hopes of finding each county diſtracted: with a barbarous, bloody murder, in every jail, and ſo live upon the calamities of mankind.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Like phyſicians, when a north-eaſt wind, a Lord Mayor's feaſt, or a jail diſtemper, has made a good ſickly time of it.

div.stage: Enter Lady BELL, and Lady JANE.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Come, ſiſter, leave the men to themſelves. Mr. Daſhwould, has their wit frightened you away?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: "Look in her face, and you forget them all."

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Won't your Ladyſhip have compaſſion on that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Compaſſion!—my ſiſter and I, we hope for his protection?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: When you go away from company, Lady Bell, you draw every body in your train.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! you have ſo overpowered me with civil, and tender things!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: What does he follow her for?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: A l'honneur, gentleman. (goes up to Millamour) Uncle! Uncle Millamour, when you are married to my aunt, I hope you will be kind to us both.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Confuſion! daggers! daggers!

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: May I ſalute you, uncle?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Po! this foolery!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Let us give him all his titles!—Brother —when you marry my Siſter.—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: How can you, Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Uncle!—Brother!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And Brother Uncle!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: This is too much —No patience can endure it. (turns to Lady Bell) Madam, this uſage— (Lady Bell and Lady Jane both laugh loud.)

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Come, ſiſter, let us leave him.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! I ſhall expire.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Why will you torment me thus? (takes her by the hand) Am I to be for ever made your ſport?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! you would not have me laugh. To be ſure, when one conſiders, it is a ſerious matter. And though Captain Bygrove (pointing to him) has orders to be in love with me; and though he has declared himſelf in the warmeſt terms—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And could you liſten to him?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And yet after all your promiſes, when you had touched my heart—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Jealous of me by this light.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: After all your faithleſs vows, to break them as you have done, like a Turk, or a Jew, or a Mahometan, (crying) and leave me, like Dido and Aeneas, it is enough to break a young girl's heart. (crying bitterly) ſo it is, it is—There, will that pleaſe you? (burſts into a laugh) Adieu, uncle! my compliments to my aunt—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Did not I hear ſomebody crying?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, and laughing too. Captain Bygrove, you ſaid ſomething to Lady Bell, what was it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: What I deſire the world to know; I love her, I adore her. My father has order'd it, Mrs. Bromley approves; Lady Bell encourages me; and I ſhall be the happieſt of mankind.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You and I muſt talk apart, Sir. You know my prior claim. Attempt my life rather than my love. You muſt think no more of her, Sir; ſhe is mine by every tie, and ſo I ſhall tell her this moment.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Now hold that reſolution, if you can.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: I have managed it well.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Admirably!

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: What does all this mean? Daſhwould, you are wanted in the next room. Malvil is in for it: he ſits toaſting Miſs Neville, while every idea fades away from his countenance, all going out one by one, and his eye ſinks into the dim vacuity of a briſk no meaning at all.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I'll look in upon them.—Bygrove, I ſee Miſs Neville: let us give Sir Harry his opportunity.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I thought Lady Bell was here: I beg your pardon; gentlemen.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Your company is always agreeable, is not it, Sir Harry? The gentleman will ſpeak for himſelf. Come, Bygrove, I have occaſion for you.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: May I now preſume, Madam—

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You chuſe your time but ill, Sir Harry. I have ſo many things to diſtract me, I cannot liſten to you now.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: But you promiſed to hear me; I have long beheld your ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: They do not warrant improper liberties. I can be humble as becomes my ſituation. I hope you will not oblige me to ſhew that ſpirit, which virtue is as much intitled to, as the proudeſt fortune in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I mean you no diſreſpect. That letter is a black artifice to traduce my character: the fraud ſhall be brought to light; you may rely upon it; nor will you be ſo ungenerous as to believe the dark aſſaſſin of my honour.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I know not what foundation there is for it, nor is it for me to charge you with any thing. I have no right to take that liberty.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Why harbour ſuſpicions unworthy of you? In me, you behold a warm admirer, who aſpires at the poſſeſſion of what he loves, and trembles for the event.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I muſt take the liberty to doubt your ſincerity. I know my own deficiencies, and Ibeg leave to withdraw.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: By all that's amiable in your mind and perſon, my views are honourable as ever yet inſpired alover's heart.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I would fain expreſs my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Why thoſe tears?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Your character, I dare ſay, Sir, will come out clear and unſullied. You will permit me to take care of mine. It is all I have to value. I ſhall not continue any longer in this houſe. Mrs. Bromley has made it impoſſible; I wiſh you all happineſs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: That reſolution I approve of: let me provide you a retreat, and in a few days—

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I muſt beg to be excuſed: that I can never think of.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: By Heaven, I mean to raiſe you to that independance, which your merit deſerves. I would place you in that ſplendor, which Mrs. Bromley may envy.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I can only return my thanks. Lady Bell will know where I am. I feel no ambition: I do not want to give pain to Mrs. Bromley: I ſeek humble content, and aſk no more.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: You do injuſtice to yourſelf and to me: —Hey! all breaking up from table!

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: You muſt not detain me now, Sir Harry. I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: I wonder what Daſh wood will ſay to all this. I ſhall like to hear him: he will turn it to a joke, I warrant him. No end of his pleaſantry.

div.stage: Enter MALVIL in liquor, BYGROVE, and DASHWOULD.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Very well; make the moſt of it. Since you force me to ſpeak, I ſay her character is a vile one.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Here is a fellow whom wine only inſpires with malice.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Po! malice! Malvil has no harm in him.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You may talk of Mrs. Bromley, but ſhe is as vile a character, as pride, and inſolence, and avarice, and vanity, and faſhionable airs, and decayed beauty can jumble together.

sp.speaker: BYO.
sp.p: Here's a return for her hoſpitality!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Marry her, I ſay; marry her, and try.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: You ſhall not have a ſhilling with Miſs Neville.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: There, the ſecret's out: you want to marry her, and make her break her word. Mankind's a villain! a medley of falſe friends, eloping wives, ſtock jobbers, and uſurers; wits that won't write, and fools that will.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Daſhwould, you are a panegyriſt, compared to this man.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Yes, he takes your trade out of your hands.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: She is Mrs. Bromley, the widow, and you are Mr. Bygrove, the widower; and ſo, bite the biter, that's all.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: His wit ſoars above you, Mr. Daſhwould.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Wit is a bad trade. Letters have no friend left in theſe degenerate times. Shew a man of letters to the firſt of your nobility, and they will leave him to ſtarve in a garret. Introduce a fellow, who can ſing a catch, write a dull political pamphlet, or remarks upon a Dutch memorial, or play off fireworks, and he ſhall paſs ſix months in the country, by invitation. Maecenas died two thouſand years ago, and you are not hiſtorian enough to know it.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: Daſhwould, he makes a bankrupt of you.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: I have found him out: I know him now: a pretended friend, that he may more ſurely betray you. Go, and get ſome coffee, to ſettle your head.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley will ſettle your head.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Let us take him up ſtairs; he'll tumble over the tea-table, to ſhew his politeneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR. [taking him by the arm]
sp.p: Come, the ladies wait for us.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mankind, I ſay, is a villain!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Mr. Malvil!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: All Daſhwould's doing to expoſe a body. Do you look to Millamour, that's what I ſay to you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: He ſhan't ſtay to plague your Ladyſhip.— Come, Malvil, let us go and be tender of reputation above ſtairs.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I'm always tender, and you are ſcurrilous.

div.stage: ſings, and Exit, led by Daſhwould and Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: How Millamour follows me up and down! Charming! here he comes.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lady Bell, allow me but one ſerious moment.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: This bracelet is always coming off.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Whatever appearances may have been, I burn with as true a paſſion, as ever penetrated a faithful heart.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I know he is mine. —This ſilly, obſtinate bauble! What were you ſaying? Oh! making love again.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: By this dear hand I ſwear—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Hold, hold, no violence. Give me my liberty, and thus I make uſe of it.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL,
sp.p: Oh! I have been wiſhing for you. How could you ſtay ſo long?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: They detained me againſt my will. But you ſee, I am true to my appointment.

sp.speaker: MIL. (aſide to Bygrove)
sp.p: Are you ſo? You ſhall keep an appointment with me.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I was ſurrounded with darts, and flames. That gentleman was for renewing the old ſtory, but it is ſo ridiculous!
sp.stage: (walks up the ſtage with Capt. Bygrove)

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Diſtraction! to be inſulted thus!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You have prevailed upon me to be in earneſt at laſt. Since your father has propoſed it, and ſince you have declared yourſelf, why, if I muſt ſpeak, get my aunt's conſent, and mine follows of courſe.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If ever I forgive this.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley has conſented (then aſide to Lady Bell) He has it; this will gall his pride.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No end of her folly. I was bent on marriage, but now it's all her own fault. And yet ſhe knows my heart is fixed upon her.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL [walking down with Capt. Bygrove]
sp.p: You are ſo obliging, and I have ſo many things to ſay to you; but if people will not perceive, when they interrupt private converſation.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If ever I enter theſe doors again, may the ſcorn of the whole ſex purſue me.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: We have carried this too far.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: The barbarous man, when he ſhould have taken no denial, but have lain on the ground, imploring, beſeeching—Delightful! here he comes again.
Is it not ſtrange, that you can't know your own mind for two minutes together?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Ho! ho! the aſſurance of that reproach!

sp.speaker: MIL. [to Bygrove]
sp.p: Appoint your time and place: I muſt have ſatisfaction for this.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: To-morrow morning, when the marriage ceremony is over.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I ſhall expect you, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: This is lucky. I was in queſt of your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: In queſt of me, Sir?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: In queſt of you, ma'am. I have been waiting for an opportunity, and, if the ſincereſt ſorrow can expiate paſt offences—Here's a chair, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG. (to Lady Bell)
sp.p: We may drive him to extremities with Lady Jane: I'll leave you to recover your wanderer.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If you will permit me to aſſure you—

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: But while my ſiſter is my rival—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Your ſiſter's charms carry their own antidote with them. If there is faith in man, I mean to attone for what is paſt.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL,
sp.p: So, ſo; with what pleaſure ſhe hears him? Did you ſpeak to me, Mr. Millamour?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There was a time, ma'am!— (turns to Lady Jane) Now ſhe wants to interrupt us: don't let us mind her, and ſhe'll withdraw.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Wear the willow, Lady Bell? Not a word, Sir? You are in the right: my ſpirits are too violent for you; and though what I ſay is not abſolutely wit—Do you like wit? I am ſure you ought; for it is undeſineable, like yourſelf.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: That is not ill ſaid.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Horrid! I ſhall be vapour'd up to my eyes. I'll try my ſong, to baniſh melancholly. Where is that fooliſh guitar?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Now her jealouſy is at work. I knew ſhe would be mortified. Let us agree to pique her pride, and probe her to the quick.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Though I can't ſing, it diverts a body to try.

l.hi: Sabrina, with that ſober mien,
The converſe ſweet, the look ſerene;
Thoſe eyes that beam the gentleſt ray,
And though ſhe loves, that ſweet delay;
Unconſcious, ſeems each heart to take,
And conquers for her ſubjects ſake!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Vaſtly well!
sp.stage: (liſtens, ſmiles, looks at her, draws his chair near her, and beats time on her knee)

l.hi: The lyrant Cynthia wings the dart,
Coquetting with a bleeding heart;
Has cruelty, which all adore,
Flights that torment, yet pleaſe the more:
Her lover ſtrives to break his chain,
But can't, ſuch pleaſure's in the pain.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Oh! charming! charming!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: What are you about, you wretch? Only look, ſiſter: I ſuppoſe, Sir, when you have done, you will give me my hand again.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: I promiſe you, ſiſter, your triumph will be ſhort.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: How ſhe flung out of the room!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You know, Lady Bell, that I am yours by conqueſt. I adore you ſtill, and burn with a lover's faithful fires.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Come, and have a diſh of tea to cool you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Hear me but a moment. It is now time you ſhould be tired of this eternal diſplay of your power. Your power is ſufficiently acknowledged and felt by all. You may triumph over adoring crouds, but one lover treated with generoſity, will be more to your honour and your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Pretty, very pretty! I have read all that in one of the poets.

l.hi: By our diſtreſs, you nothing gain,
Unleſs you love, you pleaſe in vain.

sp.p: Come up ſtairs, and I'll ſhew you the whole poem.

l.hi: And one adorer kindly us'd,
Gives more delight than crowds refus'd.

sp.p: Will you come? (beckons him) Won't you? Well, conſider of it, and when you know your own mind, you may change it again.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There now! Every thing by turns, and nothing long. Fickle do they call me? A man muſt be fickle, who purſues her through all the whimſies of her temper. Admire her in one ſhape, and ſhe takes another in a moment.

l.hi: One charm aiſplay'd, another ſtrikes our view,
In quick variety for ever new.

div.head: ACT the FIFTH.

sp.speaker: MILLAMOUR.
sp.p: AM I to be ſacrificed to your humour?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Am I to be ſacrificed to your abſurdity?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: When pleaſantry is out of all time and place—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Why then I ſhall be tired of all time and place.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Look ye, Mr. Daſhwould, it is time to be ſerious. The wit, that wounds the breaſt of a friend, is the peſt of ſociety.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The paſſion, Mr. Millamour, that runs headlong without cauſe, and will not hearken to reaſon, is a greater peſt of ſociety, than all the little with that has been in the world. What does all this mean, Sir? What is it about?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: If I loſt money at play, was it for you to carry the tale to my father? for you to ſubject me to his reproaches?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I don't know by what fatality it happens, but that generally comes laſt, which ought to be mentioned firſt. I repeated nothing to Sir John: who did? Do you aſk that queſtion? Malvil, Sir, with his uſual duplicity.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Malvil? He has this moment told me how pleaſant you were upon the ſubject, and at my expence.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Yes, when he had revealed the whole, and with falſe tenderneſs lamented your folly.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! I underſtand it now. I have been abſurd here.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I don't diſlike you for your abſurdity that ſerves to divert one: Malvil excites other feelings. You know the character he gave you of Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes, and all ſlander.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I left him but now, repreſenting you to Lady Bell in the ſame colours—And here— (ſhews a letter) Here I have him faſt. An anonymous letter againſt Sir Harry, ſent for his own purpoſes, to Miſs Neville. All his contrivance, dictated by himſelf, and written at an attorney's deſk: You know old Copyhold?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Did he pen the letter?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: One of his clerks was the ſcribe. The young man is now in the Houſe, at my requeſt, and ready to prove Malvil the author. Here he comes —things are not ripe as yet. Say nothing now.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Walk in; you come opportunely.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: If I can be of any ſervice—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: To be of diſſervice, is your province; and when you have done the miſchief, you can transfer the blame to others.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I have been rather off my guard to-day. I am not uſed to be overtaken in that manner; my head is not quite clear.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Then this buſineſs may ſober you. What was your whiſper to me about that gentleman?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: That he treated with wanton pleaſantry what I thought a ſerious matter. I may miſtake the means, but the end of my actions I can always anſwer for. Sir John might hear of the affair from another quarter, and ſo to ſoften his reſentment—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You took care to excite it.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I—I—I am apt to carry my heart at my tongue's end.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I knew his heart was not in the right place.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I did not addreſs myſelf to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I know you have the grimace of character. Mr. Malvil, arm'd at all points with plauſible maxims. But which of your maxims can juſtify the treachery of betraying the ſecret of a friend? Who does it, is a deſtoryer of all confidence; and when he attempts to varniſh his conduct, with the ſpecious name of friendſhip, the malignity ſtrikes the deeper: artful, ſmiling malignity.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: I deſerve all this. Friendſhip in exceſs is a fault. There are bounds and limits even to virtue. It would be well if a man could always hit the exact point. There is however ſomething voluptuous in meaning well.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Well expreſs'd, Malvil! ha! ha! you are right.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: No more of your muſty ſentences.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Morals are not eapable of mathematical demonſtration. And—now I recollect myſelf—It did not occur at firſt—It was Madam La Rouge told the affair to Sir John. This gentleman here—I ſuppoſe you will take his word—he ſays ſhe hears every thing, tells every thing, and he calls her a walking news-paper: not that ſhe means any harm. I only mean to ſay—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Oh! fie, don't be too ſevere upon her.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: She ſaid at the ſame time—you know her manner—ſhe told Sir John that you are in love with half a dozen, and will deceive them all, and Lady Bell into the bargain.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Diſtraction! ſhe dare not ſay it. This is another of your ſubterfuges. You know, Sir, how you traduced Lady Bell, and made that gentleman the author of your own malevolence. At any other time and place, this ſword ſhould read you a lecture of morality.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: You are too warm: and ſince I ſee it is ſo, to avoid contention, I ſhall adjourn the debate

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Deceive Lady Bell!—Whoever has dared to ſay it, —Madam La Rouge lives but a little way off. I'll bring her this moment, to confront this arch impoſtor.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You'll be ſure to return.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: This very night ſhall unmaſk him.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: I ſhall depend upon you, Malvil ſhall anſwer to Sir Harry: all his artifices ſhall be fairly laid open.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Mr. Daſhwould, we are now good friends, I have repoſed a confidence in you. You know every thing between me and Mrs. Bromley, but you ſee how ſhe goes on.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And I ſee how you go on. You are the dupe of your own policy.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: The Widow's ſchemes are ſeconded by your own imprudence. Can't you ſee, that if Millamour were once married out of your way, Mrs. Bromley would then be at her laſt ſtake, and you might have ſome chance? And yet your ſon has it in command to defeat my friend Millamour with Lady Bell.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: How! light breaks in upon me. Gull that I was! my ſon ſhall marry Lady Jane directly.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: To be ſure; and the conſequence is, that Lady Bell declares for Millamour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Right: I am for ever obliged to you: I'll go, and ſpeak to my ſon, this moment: Lady Jane ſhall be his, without delay.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: So much for my friend, the Captain: I have ſettled his buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Mr. Daſhwould, I am ſo diſtracted —a terrible buſineſs has happened.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Miſs Neville! I can't think what is become of her—ſhe is not to be found, high or low. We have ſearched every where for her. What can be the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Is Malvil gone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: This very moment: he has no hand in it. He ſees, and pities my diſtreſs. He is gone to make enquiry. A girl that I was ſo fond of, and never ſaid an angry word to.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You have been remarkably mild.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You know how tender I have been of her.—What can have put this into her head? How long has Millamour been gone?—I underſtand it now. This is his exploit.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You wrong him. I will undertake to diſcover this plot for you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You can comfort the Lady, Sir; I ſhall return immediately.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: May I take the liberty, Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Why torment me thus? You are all in a plot againſt me.

div.stage: Enter Lady BELL, Lady JANE, and Capt. BYGROVE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: There, Lady Bell, there is your lover run away with your couſin.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I can depend upon her. I can ſtill venture to anſwer for her honour.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: She will come back, you need not alarm yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: You have ſeduced her, for any thing I know. I am diſtracted by you all, and will hear no more.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley, permit me to ſay a word.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: I hope there is nothing amiſs. I can rely upon Miſs Neville's diſcretion; I think I can. Come, ſiſter, let us go and enquire. (going, looks back) Hey! you two are ſtaying, to ſay delicate things to each other.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Our difficulties, you know, are at an end. I have my father's orders to follow my inclination. Had Millamour ſtaid, I have a plot would have fixed him your Ladyſhips for ever.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: And we ſha'n't ſee him again this month, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Let him take his own way. I am only uneaſy about Miſs Neville at preſent.

div.stage: Enter DASHWOULD. (with a letter in his hand)

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: This way, you are wanted: I have a letter here, that diſcovers all.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: But what does it ſay? Let us go and hear it directly.

div.stage: Scene, an Apartment at Madam LA ROUGE'S.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Have you ſent to Daſhwould?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſend him letter.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Miſs Neville here you ſay?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: She come an hour ago, all in tear.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Then ſhe is ſafe.—You are ſure you never ſaid any thing to Sir John about the gaming buſineſs?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Sur mon honneur. What I tell? I know noting. And I not ſee Sir John in my houſe, it is two tree month.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You ſhall come, and confront Malvil at Mrs. Bromley's.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Bagatelle! what go dere for?— Bo, dis is all put me off—pay your littel bill. Vat is money to you? I ſo poor, you ſo rich.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You did not ſay that I ſhould deceive Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Monſieur Malvil, he tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Yes; and I tremble for the conſequence.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: It is one great villain—I great reſpect for you. Vous eſt aimable. Monſieur Malvil, he is great fripon. And I ver ſorry he be marry to Madamoiſelle Neville.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Married to her?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: You not know it?—He is marry to her dis day. He take my apartment tree week ago. He not have it known dat he is marry for five ſix day; write letter to me dis afternoon; he muſt be let in ver private; de ſervant not to ſee him; go up de back ſtairs to her room, and ſo l' affaire eſt faite.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: And thus he has ſeduced her from her relations? Let me ſee the letter.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: I not tink him ſo bad to talk of me, and tell ſuch parcel of ſtory, vid not one word of true.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: So; here he is in black and white. To come privately, is he? If I could detain him here, and prevent all means of an eſcape—

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Eſcape? Up back ſtairs, he muſt come thro' dat apartment; (pointing to a door in the back ſcene) I turn de key in de back door: viola votre priſonier; he is priſoner.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Exquiſite woman! I'll lock this door, and ſecure the key. (locks the door in the back ſcene) Huſh!

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Le voila: he come now.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Fly, let him in; ſend once more to Daſhwould; I want him this inſtant; fly, diſpatch.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: I do all vat you bid me

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: It is honeſt of her to make this diſcovery. If this be Malvil—a ſoft whiſper that— (liſtens) 'Tis he, I hear his voice—I ſhall have the merit of defeating villany, and protecting innocence—Don't I hear Miſs Neville? (goes to a room door) Miſs Neville!

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Madam La Rouge!—Oh, Sir! what brings you hither?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: It is your intereſt to hear me; your happineſs depends upon it.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Alas! I fear I have been too raſh.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Command your attention, and liſten to me: Malvil has planned your ruin.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Impoſſible: • e has too much honour: why will you alarm me thus? I am unfortunate, and you, Sir, need not add to my afflictions.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You have truſted yourſelf to a villain: he means, at midnight, to gain acceſs to your perſon; to triumph over your honour, and then leave you to remorſe, to ſhame, and miſery. Read that letter. (gives it her, and ſhe reads it to herſelf) She's an amiable girl, and I dare ſay, will make an admirable wife—Hark! I hear him in yonder room. Suppreſs each wild emotion of ſurprize, and wait the event.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I can ſcarce believe what I read. What have I done? (weeps) You have led me into a maze of doubts and fears, and there I wander, diſtracted, loſt; without a clue to guide me.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I will direct you: rely upon me.

div.stage: Enter DASHWOULD, Lady BELL, and Lady JANE.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: La Rouge has told us the whole ſtory.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Huſh! no noiſe.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: My ſweet girl, how could you frighten me ſo?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: I bluſh for what I have done. But Mrs. Bromley's cruelty drove me to diſpair.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: My dear, all will be well: don't flurry yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Tho' my aunt vexed you, why run away from me?

div.stage: Enter Mrs. BROMELY, BYGROVE, Sir HARRY, and Capt. BYGROVE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Where is this unhappy girl?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: A moment's patience.

sp.speaker: MIL
sp.p: Is he ſafe?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: He is dere in de room as ſafe as in Baſtile.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Speak to him thro' the door: now all be ſilent.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Monſieur Malvil, open de door.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Do you open it, you have the key.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: De key, it is dere: Miſs Neville, it is gone to bed; all de houſe aſleep: I in de dark; now is your time.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Huſh! here is the key.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Will you diſpatch?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Attendez: here is de key: I let you out.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: All in darkneſs: Is ſhe gone to bed?

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: She wait for you: vere was you married?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: St. James's pariſh: Sir Harry has not ſucceeded: ſhe prefers me. Say nothing of it yet awhile.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: No; not a vord: tenez, I get light for you.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: So; I have carried my point. The family will be glad to patch up the affair, to avoid the diſgrace.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE. (entering).
sp.p: Ah! you look en cavalier; ver good apartment for you; and dere is good picture. It is Tarquin and Lucrece; Tarquin go to raviſh de lady in the night. It was villain, was it not?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: A terrible fellow!

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: And dis room it is velle furniſh: look about you; more picture, and all original.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! your ſervant Mr. Ivlalvil!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Hell and confuſion!

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: There are bounds and limits even to virtue.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Morals are capable of mathematical demonſtration.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Let us withdraw from all this buſtle. Sir Harry, ſtep this way, I want you.

div.stage: Exit with Miſs Neville, Lady Jane, and Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: This is all according to the fitneſs of things.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Something voluptuous in meaning well.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Daſhwould, your ridicule is now in ſeaſon to expoſe ſuch a character. He is fair game, and hunt him down as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: LA ROUGE.
sp.p: Ah! Monſieur Tartuffe!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The fiends about me!—Mr. Bygrove, you are a thinking man, I appeal to you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: I appeal to this letter, Sir.

body.p: Miſs Neville has this day given me her hand in marriage. I would not have it known for ſome time. Conduct me to her apartments, unknown to your ſervants. The way up the back ſtairs will be beſt. Your ſecrecy ſhall be rewarded by

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The letter is forged—let me ſee it.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And I have another proof! this anonymous ſcrowl, written by your direction, and ſent to Miſs Neville, to give a ſtab to the character of Sir Harry. Do you deny it, Sir? Your ſecretary is now in the houſe; I brought him with me; he is ready to prove you the author of this mean, clandeſtine miſchief.

sp.speaker: MAL:
sp.p: All falſe; all a forgery. Where is this French impoſtor? Where is your witneſs, Sir? (to Daſhwood) I'll put them both to the proof this moment.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: No private parlying.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: No; we muſt all hear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Yes; all muſt hear.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: My preſence may be neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Millamour, ſtay and give me joy.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: The idol of my heart! To-morrow makes her mine.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Well, I give you joy. Who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: My Lady Bell, thou dear fellow: come, let us go and ſee what they are about.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Let us go and ſee who ſhall cut the other's throat.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: A pleaſant employment.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You ſhall tear this heart out, before you tear Lady Bell from me.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: Very well; have your frolic—This works as I could wiſh.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Deſpair and phrenzy! if ſhe is capable of a treachery like this—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You have done ſome good at laſt, Mr. Millamour.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lady Bell! (pauſes and looks at her) I once thought—but you will break my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: It will bend a little, but never break.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Will you liſten to me? There is a tyrant fair, and you have intereſt with her; you can ſerve me; all the joys of life are center'd there.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: He is mine againſt the world. And ſo you want my intereſt? That's lucky, for I have a favour to requeſt of you.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Is there a favour in the power of man, you may not command at my hands?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You are very good, Sir; there is a a perſon, but the levity of his temper—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She means me—Your beauty will reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: May I rely upon you?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: What an angel look there was! And do you aſk the queſtion?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: When ſincere affection—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: It is generous to own it.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And ſince the impreſſion made by—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Do not heſitate.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Made by Captain Bygrove—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Made by Captain Bygrove!

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: That wounds deep—and if you will aſſiſt my fond, fond hopes, —it will be generous indeed.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p:
This is a blow I never looked for—Yes, ma'am, it will be generous, —and in return, if you
will intercede for me with Lady Bell—po! with a— with Lady Jane, I ſay—I ſay if you will intercede for me with Lady Jane—

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Oh! by all means. And as I approve of your choice, (he walks away, ſhe follows him) I hope you will approve of mine; and by mutual acts of friendſhip, we may promote each other's happineſs.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Malvil is detected.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: And Sir Harry has ſettled every thing with Miſs Neville. Go and wiſh hm joy. (Exit Daſhwould) My ſweet friend will be happy at laſt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: But you won't marry the Captain?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Will you make intereſt for me?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: How can you torment me thus?

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: You have done ſome ſervice, and you may now entertain a degree of hope. (ſmiling at him) But have you another copy of verſes for my aunt?

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: How can you? (kiſſes her hand; Exit Lady Bell)—She yields, and I am bleſſed indeed.

div.stage: Enter BYGROVE, MALVIL, and Capt. BYGROVE.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: The fact is too clear, Mr. Malvil.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: And ſhall the word of that French impoſtor—

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: She has acted fairly, Sir; what reparation can you make the lady, whoſe ruin you have attempted?

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley promiſed her a fortune, and I have promiſed her marriage.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And I forbid the banns. Sir Harry has concluded a match with Miſs Neville: I ſhould have thought him ridiculous if he had not.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: That you will do, whether he deſerves it or not.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: You, Sir, deſerve ſomething worſe than ridicule. You are thoroughly underſtood. Your tenderneſs for your neighbour, is malignant curioſity; your half hints, that heſitate ſlander, ſpeak the louder; and your ſilence, that affects to ſuppreſs what you know, is a mute, that ſtrangles.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The probity of my character, Sir—

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Ay, probity is the word. He has had pretty perquiſites from his probity; legacies, truſt money, and the confidence of families. For aught I ſee, probity is as good a trade as any a going.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: The ſtill voice of truth is loſt: you are all in a combination.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: And you have forced me to be of the number.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley! you will judge with candour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, it is all too plain.

sp.speaker: MAL.
sp.p: It is in vain to contend: I ſhall be cautious what I ſay of any of you: my heart is with you all.

sp.speaker: BYG
sp.p: Farewel, hypocrite!

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

div.stage: Enter Lady BELL, Miſs NEVILLS, Sir HARRY, and Lady JANE.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p:
Here, Sir Harry, in the preſence of this company, I give you, in this friend of mine,
truth, good ſenſe, and virtue. Take her, Sir, and now you have got a treaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
sp.p: It ſhall be my pride to raiſe you to that ſphere of life, which your merit, and your ſufferings from—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Why fix on me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir HAR.
