sp.p: They are much miſtaken, who can find no way of ſhewing their ſuperior rank, but by letting their weight fall on thoſe, whom fortune has placed beneath them.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: And that ſentiment, however I may rattle, I wiſh impreſſed upon all the patrons of poor relations, throughout his Majeſty's dominions.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEV.
sp.p: Mrs. Bromley, I have much to ſay to you. My obligations to you I ſhall never forget. I am not aſhamed, even in the preſence of Sir Harry, to own the diſtreſs in which you found me. If at any time I have given offence; if under your diſpleaſure, I have been impatient, you will allow for an education that raiſed me much above my circumſtances. That education ſhall teach me to act as becomes Sir Harry's Lady, with affection, with duty to him; and to you, madam, with gratitude, for that bounty which ſaved me from calamity and ruin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: Your words overpower me. I feel that I have done wrong. I now ſee, that to demand in return, for favours conferred, an abject ſpirit, and mean compliance, is the worſt uſury ſociety knows of. I rejoice at your good fortune: your merit deſerves it.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Why this is as it ſhould be.—Mr. Bygrove, I hope ſoon to wiſh you joy.

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: Compared to Malvil, thou art an honeſt fellow, and I thank you.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: Millamour, is there no recompence for your virtue? in a modern comedy, you would be rewarded with a wife.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Lady Bell has more than poetical juſtice in her power. I wiſh Sir John were here: he would now ſee me reclaimed from every folly, by that lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BROM.
sp.p: If it is ſo, I congratulate you both.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: It is even ſo, aunt; the whim of the preſent moment. Mr. Millamour has ſerved my amiable friend, and I have promiſed him my hand— and ſo— (holds up both hands) which will you have? Puzzle about it, and know your own mind if you can.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: With rapture thus I ſnatch it to my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: Siſter, what nunnery will you go to? Mr. Bygrove, command your ſon to take her.

sp.speaker: Capt. BYG.
sp.p: That command I have obeyed already.

sp.speaker: Lady JANE.
sp.p: Since the truth muſt out; we made uſe of a ſtratagem to fix my ſiſter, and that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady BELL.
sp.p: To fix yourſelf, if you pleaſe I knew you would be married before me.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Daſhwould, give me your hand. Your wit ſhall enliven our ſocial hours, and while I laugh with you at the events of life, you ſhall ſee me endeavour to weed out of my own mind every folly.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: You do me honour, Sir. And, if Mr. Bygrove will now and then give and take a joke—

sp.speaker: BYG.
sp.p: As often as you pleaſe:—but take my advice, and don't loſe your friend for your joke.

sp.speaker: DASH.
sp.p: By no means, Mr. Bygrove, —except now and then, when the friend is the worſt of the two.

sp.speaker: MIL.
sp.p: Come, gentlemen, your differences are all at an end. Lady Bell, the varieties of life, till now, diſtracted my attention.

div.l: But when our hearts victorious beauty draws,
We feel its pow'r, and own its ſovereign laws;
To that ſubſervient all our paſſions move,
And even my conſtancy ſhall ſpring from love.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: Written by Mr. GARRICK. Spoken by Mrs. MATTOCKS.

lg.l: IF after Tragedy 'tis made a rule,
To jeſt no more, I'll be no titt'ring fool,
To jog you with a joke in Tragic doze,
And ſhake the dew-drops from the weeping roſe,
Prudes of each ſex affirm, and who denies?
That in each tear a whimp'ring Cupid lies.
To ſuch wiſe, formal folk, my anſwer's ſimple;
A thouſand Cupids revel in a dimple!
From their ſoft neſts, with laughter out they ruſh,
Perch'd on your heads, like ſmall birds in a buſh.
Beauty reſiſtlefs in each ſmile appears:
Are you for dimples, ladies, or for tears?
Dare they in Comedy our mirth abridge?
Let us ſtand up for giggling privilege;
Aſſert our rights, that laughter is no ſin,
From the ſcrew'd ſimper, to the broad-fac'd grin.
So much for ſelf; now turn we to the Poet:
"KNOW YOUR OWN MIND"—Are any here who know it?
To know one's mind is a hard taſk indeed,
And harder ſtill for us, by all agreed.
Cards, balls, beaux, feathers, round the eddy whirling,
Change every moment, while the hair is curling.
The Greeks ſay—"Know Thyſelf"—I'm ſure I find,
I Know Myſelf that I don't Know my Mind.
Know YOU your minds, wiſe Men?—Come, let us try.
I have a worthy cit there in my eye;
Tho' he to ſneer at us takes much delight,
He cannot fix where he ſhall go to-night:
His pleaſure and his peace are now at ſtrife,
He loves his bottle, and he fears his wife.
He'll quit this houſe, not knowing what to do;
The Ska • eſpeare's Head firſt gives a pull or two
But with a ſideling ſtruggle he gets thro';
Darts acroſs Ruſſel-ſtreet: then with new charms,
The Syren, Luxury, his boſom warms,
And draws him in the vortex of the Bedford Arms.
Happy this night!—But when comes wife and ſorrow?

l.hi: "To morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow."

lg.l: I ſee ſome laughers here; pray which of you
Know your own Minds?—in all this houſe but few!
Wits never know their Minds;—our Minor Bards,
Changing from bad to worſe, now ſpin Charades.
O'er Law and Phyſic we will draw a curtain;
There nothing but uncertainty is certain.
Grave looks, wigs, coats, —the Doctors now relingquiſh'em,
They're right—from Undertakers to diſtinguiſh'em.
The Courtiers, do' em juſtice, never doubt,
Whether' tis better to be in or out.
Some Patriots too, know their own mind and plan;
They're firmly fix'd, to get in when they can;
Gameſters don't waver; they all hazards run,
For ſome muſt cheat, and more muſt be undone.
Great Stateſmen know-their minds, but ne'er reveal'om;
We never know theirſecrets, 'till we feel them.
Grant me a favour, Critics: don't ſay nay;
Be of one mind with me, and like this Play.
Thence will two wonders riſe: Wits will be kind,
Noy more—behold, a Woman Knows her Mind!
